text: “The people, their ancestors, and the kings of Judah have abandoned me. They have made this place unrecognizable by burning incense as an offering to other gods that they hadn’t heard of. They have filled this place with the blood of innocent people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have built worship sites to burn their children as sacrifices to Baal. I didn’t ask them or command them to do this. It never entered my mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why the days are coming, declares the Lord, when this place will no longer be called Topheth or the valley of Ben Hinnom. Instead, it will be called Slaughter Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will smash the plans of Judah and Jerusalem in this place. I will cut them down with swords in front of their enemies and with the hands of those who want to kill them. I will give their bodies as food to birds and to animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will devastate this city. It will become something to hiss at. Everyone who goes by it will be stunned and hiss with contempt at all the disasters that happen to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the people eat the flesh of their sons and daughters. They will eat each other’s flesh during blockades and hardships that their enemies impose on them when they want to kill them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord says, “Then smash the jar in front of the men who went with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies says: I will smash these people and this city as this potter’s jar was smashed beyond repair. They will bury the dead in Topheth until there’s no other place to bury them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s what I will do to this place and to those who live in it, declares the Lord. I will make this city like Topheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The houses in Jerusalem, the houses of the kings of Judah, and all the rooftops of the houses will be unclean  like this city Topheth. This is because people burned incense to the entire army of heaven and poured out wine offerings to other gods.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah left Topheth, where the Lord had sent him to prophesy. He stood in the courtyard of the Lord’s temple and said to all the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I’m going to bring on this city and on all its towns the disasters that I threatened. They’ve become impossible to deal with, and they refuse to obey me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the priest, Immer’s son Pashhur, the chief officer of the Lord’s temple, heard Jeremiah prophesying these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pashhur struck the prophet Jeremiah and put him in prison at Upper Benjamin Gate that was in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day when Pashhur took Jeremiah out of prison, Jeremiah said to him, “The Lord doesn’t call you Pashhur, but he calls you Terror Everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: I’m going to make you terrify yourself and all your friends. Their enemies’ swords will kill them, and you will see it with your own eyes. I will hand all of Judah over to the king of Babylon. He will take the people away as captives to Babylon or kill them with swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand all the riches of this city over to their enemies. This will include all its produce, all its valuables, and all the treasures of the kings of Judah. Their enemies will loot them, take them away, and bring them to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, Pashhur, and all those who live in your house will go into captivity. You will go to Babylon, and you will die there. You will be buried there together with all your friends to whom you prophesied these lies.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, you have deceived me, and I was deceived.
You overpowered me and won.
I’ve been made fun of all day long.
Everyone mocks me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each time I speak, I have to cry out and shout,
“Violence and destruction!”
The Lord’s word has made me the object of insults
and contempt all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I think to myself, “I can forget the Lord
and no longer speak his name.”
But his word is inside me like a burning fire shut up in my bones.
I wear myself out holding it in, but I can’t do it any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have heard many people whispering,
“Terror is everywhere!
Report him! Let’s report him!”
All my closest friends are waiting to see me stumble.
They say, “Maybe he will be tricked.
Then we can overpower him and take revenge on him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord is on my side like a terrifying warrior.
That is why those who persecute me will stumble. They can’t win.
They will be very ashamed that they can’t succeed.
Their eternal shame will not be forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord of Armies examines the righteous.
He sees their motives and thoughts.
I want to see you take revenge on them,
because I’ve brought my case to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing to the Lord! Praise the Lord!
He has rescued the lives of needy people
from the power of wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is the day that I was born,
the day that my mother gave birth to me.
May it not be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is the man who made my father very happy with the news
that he had just become the father of a baby boy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May that man be like the cities
that the Lord destroyed without pity.
May he hear a cry of alarm in the morning
and a battle cry at noon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only he had killed me while I was in the womb.
Then my mother would have been my grave,
and she would have always been pregnant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did I come out of the womb?
All I’ve seen is trouble and grief.
I will finish my days in shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah when King Zedekiah sent Pashhur, son of Malchiah, and the priest Zephaniah, son of Maaseiah, to Jeremiah. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Consult the Lord for us, because King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon is attacking us. Maybe the Lord will perform miracles for us so that Nebuchadnezzar will retreat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah responded to them, “This is what you should say to Zedekiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is what the Lord God of Israel says: I’m going to take your weapons away from you. You are using these weapons to fight the king of Babylon as well as the Babylonians who are now blockading you outside the wall. I will bring the Babylonians inside this city.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will fight you in anger, fury, and rage with my powerful hand and my mighty arm.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will defeat those who live in this city, both people and animals. They will die from a terrible plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, declares the Lord, I will hand over Judah’s King Zedekiah, his officials, the people, and everyone else in this city who survives the plague, war, and famine. They will be handed over to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and to their enemies who want to kill them. Nebuchadnezzar will kill them with swords. He won’t spare them, show them compassion, or care for them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to these people, ‘This is what the Lord says: I am going to give you the choice of life or death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who live in this city will die in the war, famine, or plague. Those of you who go out and surrender to the Babylonians will live. You will escape with your lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve decided to harm this city, not to do good to it, declares the Lord. It will be handed over to the king of Babylon, and he will burn it down.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the nation of the king of Judah, ‘Listen to the Lord’s word,
speaker: Narrator

text:
descendants of David. This is what the Lord says:
Judge fairly every morning.
Rescue those who have been robbed from those who oppress them.
Otherwise, my fury will break out and burn like fire.
No one will be able to put it out
because of the evil things you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘I’m against you, Jerusalem.
You are the city that is in the valley
and on the rock in the plain,’ ”
declares the Lord.
“ ‘But you ask, “Who can attack us?
Who can enter our places of refuge?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘I will punish you because of the evil things you have done,’ ”
declares the Lord.
“ ‘I will start a fire in your forests,
and it will burn up everything around you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: Go to the palace of the king of Judah, and speak this message there:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to the Lord’s word, you officials, you people who come into these gates, and you, king of Judah, the one sitting on David’s throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: Judge fairly, and do what is right. Rescue those who have been robbed from those who oppress them. Don’t mistreat foreigners, orphans, or widows, and don’t oppress them. Don’t kill innocent people in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do what I say, then the kings who sit on David’s throne will ride through the gates of this palace in chariots and on horses along with their officials and their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t do what I say, I will take an oath on myself,” declares the Lord, “that this palace will become a pile of rubble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord says about the palace of the king of Judah:
This palace is like Gilead to me,
like the top of Lebanon.
I will certainly turn it into a desert,
into cities that no one lives in.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will send people to destroy you.
They will have their own weapons.
They will cut down your finest cedar trees
and throw them on a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “People from many nations will pass by this city and ask each other, ‘Why has the Lord done this to this important city?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The answer will be: ‘They rejected the promise  of the Lord their God. They worshiped other gods and served them.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t cry for the dead.
Don’t shake your heads at them.
Cry bitterly for those who are taken away,
because they won’t come back to see their homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says about King Josiah’s son Shallum, who succeeded his father as king of Judah and left this place: He will never come back here again.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will die in the place where he was taken captive, and he will never see this land again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How horrible it will be for the person who builds his house dishonestly
and his upper rooms through injustice.
He makes his neighbors work for nothing
and doesn’t pay them for their work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He says, ‘I will build a large house for myself with big upper rooms.’
He cuts out windows in it,
panels the rooms with cedar,
and paints them red.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you think you’re a better king than others
because you use more cedar?
Your father ate and drank and did what is fair and right.
Everything went well for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He defended the cause of the poor and needy.
Everything went well for him.
Isn’t this what it means to know me?” asks the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But your eyes and your mind are set on nothing but dishonest profits.
You kill innocent people and violently oppress your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says about Jehoiakim, son of Judah’s King Josiah:
People won’t mourn for him and say,
“How horrible it is for my brother and sister!”
They won’t mourn for him and say,
“How horrible it is for my master and his splendor!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will receive a donkey’s burial.
He will be dragged off and thrown outside the gates of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Go to Lebanon and cry! Raise your voice in Bashan!
Cry out from Abarim, because all your lovers are defeated.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I spoke to you when you were prosperous,
but you said that you wouldn’t listen.
This is how you’ve been ever since you were young.
You don’t listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wind will blow away all your shepherds,
and your lovers will go into captivity.
Then you will be ashamed and disgraced by all your wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You live in Lebanon and have your nest in the cedars.
But you will groan when pain strikes you,
pain like a woman giving birth to a child.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I live,” declares the Lord, “even though you, Jehoiakin, son of Judah’s King Jehoiakim, are the signet ring on my right hand, I will pull you off my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand you over to those who want to kill you, those you fear—King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and the Babylonians.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will throw you and your mother into another land. You weren’t born there, but you will die there.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will want to return to this land, but you won’t be allowed to come home.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This Jehoiakin is like a rejected and broken pot that no one wants.
Is that why he and his descendants will be thrown out
and cast into another land they’ve never heard of?
speaker: Narrator

text:
O land, land, land!
Listen to the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
Write this about Jehoiakin: He will be childless.
He won’t prosper in his lifetime.
None of his descendants will succeed him as king.
They won’t sit on David’s throne and rule Judah again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How horrible it will be for the shepherds who are destroying and scattering the sheep in my care,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what I, the Lord God of Israel, said to the shepherds who take care of my people: You have scattered my sheep and chased them away. You have not taken care of them, so now I will take care of you by punishing you for the evil you have done,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I will gather the remaining part of my flock from all the countries where I chased them. I will bring them back to their pasture, and they will be fertile and increase in number.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put shepherds over them. Those shepherds will take care of them. My sheep will no longer be afraid or terrified, and not one of them will be missing,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The days are coming,” declares the Lord,
“when I will grow a righteous branch for David.
He will be a king who will rule wisely.
He will do what is fair and right in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In his lifetime, Judah will be saved,
and Israel will live in safety. This is the name that he will be given: The Lord is our righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why the days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when people’s oaths will no longer be, ‘The Lord brought the people of Israel out of Egypt. As the Lord lives….’
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, their oaths will be, ‘The Lord brought the descendants of the nation of Israel out of the land of the north and all the lands where he  had scattered them. As the Lord lives….’ At that time they will live in their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Say this about the prophets:
I am deeply disturbed.
All my bones tremble.
I am like a drunk,
like a person who has had too much wine,
because of the Lord and his holy words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The land is filled with adulterers.
The land mourns because of the curse.
Pastures in the wilderness have dried up.
The people are evil,
and they use their strength to do the wrong things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The prophets and priests are godless.
Even in my temple I’ve found them doing evil,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That is why their own way will become
like slippery paths in the dark.
They will be chased away, and they will fall down in the dark.
I will bring disaster on them.
It is time for them to be punished,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Say this about the prophets of Samaria:
I saw something disgusting.
The prophets of Samaria prophesied by Baal
and led my people Israel astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Say this about the prophets of Jerusalem:
I see something horrible.
The prophets of Jerusalem commit adultery and live a lie.
They support those who do evil
so that no one turns back from his wickedness.
They are all like Sodom to me,
and those who live in Jerusalem are like Gomorrah.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says about the prophets:
I will give them wormwood to eat and poison to drink.
The prophets of Jerusalem have spread godlessness
throughout the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
Don’t listen to what the prophets are saying to you.
They fill you with false hope.
They speak about visions that they dreamed up.
These visions are not from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They keep saying to those who despise me,
“The Lord says, ‘Everything will go well for you.’ ”
They tell all who live by their own stubborn ways,
“Nothing bad will happen to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is in the Lord’s inner circle
and sees and hears his word?
Who pays attention and listens to his word?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The storm of the Lord will come with his anger.
Like a windstorm, it will swirl down on the heads of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The anger of the Lord will not turn back
until he has done everything he intends to do.
In the last days you will understand this clearly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I didn’t send these prophets,
yet they ran with their message.
I didn’t speak to them,
yet they prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they had been in my inner circle,
they would have announced my words to my people.
They would have turned back from their evil ways
and the evil they have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am a God who is near.
I am also a God who is far away,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“No one can hide so that I can’t see him,” declares the Lord.
“I fill heaven and earth!” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve heard the prophets who speak lies in my name. They say, ‘I had a dream! I had a dream!’
speaker: Narrator

text: How long will these prophets continue to lie and deceive?
speaker: Narrator

text: They tell each other the dreams they had, because they want to make my people forget my name, as their ancestors forgot my name because of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet who has a dream should tell his dream. However, the person who has my word should honestly speak my word. What does grain have to do with straw?” asks the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Isn’t my word like fire or like a hammer that shatters a rock?” asks the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m against the prophets who steal my words from each other,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m against the prophets who speak their own thoughts and say that they speak for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m against those who prophesy dreams they made up,” declares the Lord. “They tell the dreams they made up and lead my people astray with their lies and their wild talk. I didn’t send them or command them to go. They don’t help these people at all,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When these people, the prophets, or the priests ask you, ‘What revelation has the Lord burdened you with now?’ say to them, ‘You are the burden! I will abandon you, declares the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose the prophets, the priests, or these people say, ‘This is the Lord’s revelation!’ I will punish them and their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: They should ask their neighbors and their relatives, ‘What is the Lord’s answer?’ and ‘What did the Lord say?’
speaker: Narrator

text: They should never again say, ‘This is the Lord’s revelation,’ because each person’s word becomes the revelation. They will twist the words of the living God, the Lord of Armies, our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Jeremiah, say this to the prophets, ‘What was the Lord’s answer to you?’ and ‘What did the Lord say?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose they say, ‘This is the Lord’s revelation!’ Then say, ‘This is what the Lord says: Because you have said, “This is the Lord’s revelation!” even though I commanded you not to repeat this saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will certainly forget you. I will throw you out of my presence and out of the city that I gave you and your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring eternal disgrace and shame on you. It will never be forgotten.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon took Jehoiakin  (son of King Jehoiakim of Judah), the princes of Judah, the skilled workers, and the builders from Jerusalem into captivity and brought them to Babylon. After this, the Lord showed me two baskets of figs set in front of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: One basket had very good figs, like figs that ripen first. The other basket had very bad figs. These figs were so bad that they couldn’t be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord asked me, “What do you see, Jeremiah?”
I answered, “Figs. Figs that are very good. I also see figs that are very bad, so bad that they can’t be eaten.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: The captives of Judah, whom I sent away from here to Babylon, are like these good figs. I will look kindly on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will watch over them for their own good, and I will bring them back to this land. I will build them up and not tear them down. I will plant them and not uproot them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give them the desire to know that I am the Lord. They will be my people, and I will be their God, because they will wholeheartedly come back to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But this is what the Lord says about the bad figs that are so bad that they can’t be eaten. The Lord says, ‘Like these bad figs, I will abandon King Zedekiah of Judah, his princes, the remaining few in Jerusalem who stayed behind in this land, and those who are living in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make them a horrifying sight to all the kingdoms of the earth. They will be a disgrace and an example. They will become something ridiculed and cursed wherever I scatter them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send wars, famines, and plagues until they disappear from the land that I gave to them and their ancestors.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah about all the people of Judah when Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, was in his fourth year as king. (This was the first year that Nebuchadnezzar was king of Babylon.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Jeremiah spoke to all the people of Judah and to everyone who lived in Jerusalem. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “For 23 years, from the time that Josiah, son of Amon, was in his thirteenth year as king of Judah until today, the Lord continued to speak his word to me. So I have spoken to you again and again, but you have not listened.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Even though the Lord has sent all his servants the prophets to you, you haven’t listened or paid attention to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophets said, ‘Turn from your evil ways and the evil you have done, and live in the land that the Lord permanently gave to you and your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t follow other gods to serve and worship them. Don’t make me furious about the idols your hands have shaped. Then I won’t harm you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you haven’t listened to me, declares the Lord. You have made me furious about the idols your hands have shaped and have brought harm upon yourselves.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies says: You did not listen to my words,
speaker: Narrator

text: so I’m going to send for all the families from the north. I will also send for my servant King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, declares the Lord. I will bring the families from the north to attack this land, its people, and all these surrounding nations. I’m going to destroy them and turn them into something terrible, something ridiculed, and something permanently ruined.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take from them the sounds of joy and happiness, the sounds of brides and grooms, the sound of mills, and the light of lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: This whole land will be ruined and become a wasteland. These nations will serve the king of Babylon for 70 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the 70 years are over, I will punish the king of Babylon and that nation for their crimes, declares the Lord. I will turn Babylon into a permanent wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring on that land all the disasters I threatened to do to it, everything that Jeremiah prophesied against all the nations, everything written in this book.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many nations and great kings will make slaves of the people of Babylon, and I will pay them back for what they have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God of Israel said to me: Take from my hand this cup filled with the wine of my fury, and make all the nations to whom I’m sending you drink from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they drink from it, they will stagger and go insane because of the wars that I’m going to send them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I took the cup from the Lord’s hand. I made all the nations to whom the Lord sent me drink from it:
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerusalem and the cities of Judah as well as its kings and officials. When they drank from it, they became wastelands and ruins, something ridiculed and cursed, until today.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also made these people drink from it: Pharaoh king of Egypt, his servants, officials, all his people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the foreign people living among them; all the kings of the land of Uz; all the kings of Philistia, those from the cities of Ashkelon, Gaza, and Ekron, and the people left in Ashdod;
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom, Moab, and the people of Ammon;
speaker: Narrator

text: all the kings of Tyre and Sidon, and the kings on the seacoast;
speaker: Narrator

text: Dedan, Tema, Buz, and all who shave the hair on their foreheads;
speaker: Narrator

text: all the kings of Arabia, and all the kings of the foreign people living in the desert;
speaker: Narrator

text: all the kings of Zimri, all the kings of Elam, and all the kings of Media;
speaker: Narrator

text: all the kings of the north, near and far, one after another—all the kingdoms of the earth. Last of all, the king of Sheshach will drink from the cup.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Drink, get drunk, vomit, fall down, and don’t get up because of the wars that I’m going to send you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they refuse to take the cup from your hand and drink from it, say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies says: You must drink from it!
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to bring disaster on the city that is named after me. Do you think you’ll go unpunished? You will not go unpunished! I’m declaring war on all those who live on earth, declares the Lord of Armies.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That is why you will prophesy all these things to them and say,
‘The Lord roars from above.
He thunders from his holy dwelling place.
He roars against his land.
He shouts like those who stomp grapes.
He shouts against all those who live on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sound is echoing to the ends of the earth
because the Lord has brought charges against the nations.
He will judge all humans.
He will kill the wicked, declares the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord of Armies says:
Disaster is spreading from nation to nation.
A great storm is brewing from the distant corners of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day those killed by the Lord will stretch from one end of the earth to the other. They will not be mourned, taken away, or buried. They will become like manure on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mourn, you shepherds, and cry.
Roll in the dust, you leaders of the flock.
The time has come for you to be slaughtered.
The time has come for you to be scattered,
and you will break like fine pottery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There will be no place for the shepherds to flee,
no escape for the leaders of the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The shepherds are crying
and the leaders of the flock are mourning
because the Lord is stripping their pasture.
speaker: Narrator

text: The peaceful pastures are destroyed by the Lord’s burning anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has left his lair like a lion.
Their land has been ruined
because of the heat of the oppressor,
because of the fury of his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word when Judah’s King Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, began to rule. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: Stand in the courtyard of the Lord’s temple, and speak to all the people who come from the cities of Judah to worship in the Lord’s temple. Tell them everything that I command you to tell them. Don’t leave out a single word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maybe they’ll listen, and they’ll turn from their evil ways. Then I’ll change my plan about the disaster I intend to bring on them because of the evil they have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord added, “Also say to them, ‘This is what the Lord says: Suppose you don’t listen to me and don’t follow my teachings that I set in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose you don’t listen to the words of my servants the prophets, whom I sent to you again and again, even though you didn’t listen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will do to this temple what I did to Shiloh. I will turn this city into something that will be cursed by all the nations on earth.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests, the prophets, and all the people heard Jeremiah speaking these things in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as soon as Jeremiah finished saying everything that the Lord had commanded him to say, the priests, the prophets, and all the people grabbed him and said, “You must die!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you prophesy in the Lord’s name that this temple will be like Shiloh and this city will become a pile of rubble with no one living here?” Then all the people crowded around Jeremiah in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officials of Judah heard about these things, they went from the king’s palace to the Lord’s temple. They sat at the entrance of New Gate to the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priests and the prophets said to the officials and all the people, “This man is condemned to die because he prophesied against this city as you yourselves have heard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah said to all the officials and all the people, “The Lord sent me to prophesy everything that you have heard me say against this temple and against this city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, change your ways and what you are doing, and listen to the Lord your God. Then the Lord will change his plan about the disaster that he intends to bring on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My life is in your hands. Do with me whatever you think is good and right.
speaker: Narrator

text: But know for certain that if you put me to death, you, this city, and the people living in it will be guilty of killing an innocent person. The Lord has certainly sent me to speak all these things to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the officials and all the people said to the priests and prophets, “This man should not be condemned to die. He has spoken to us in the name of the Lord our God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some of the leaders in the land got up and said to the entire crowd,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Micah from Moresheth prophesied at the time of Judah’s King Hezekiah and said to all the people of Judah, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies says:
Zion will be plowed like a field,
Jerusalem will become a pile of rubble,
and the temple mountain will become a worship site
covered with trees.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Did Judah’s King Hezekiah and all the people of Judah put Micah to death? No! Hezekiah feared the Lord and sought the Lord’s favor. So the Lord changed his plan about the disaster he intended to bring on them. But we are about to bring a bigger disaster on ourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There was another man prophesying in the name of the Lord. His name was Uriah, son of Shemaiah, from Kiriath Jearim. He prophesied against this city and this land as Jeremiah did.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Jehoiakim and all his personal troops and officials heard what Uriah said, the king wanted to put him to death. But Uriah heard about it and fled in fear to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoiakim sent soldiers to Egypt: Elnathan (son of Achbor) and other soldiers along with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought Uriah from Egypt and took him to King Jehoiakim. The king executed Uriah and threw his body into the burial ground for the common people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahikam, son of Shaphan, supported Jeremiah. So Jeremiah was not handed over to the people to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zedekiah, son of King Josiah of Judah, began to rule, the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord said to me: Make leather straps and a wooden yoke, and strap the yoke on your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then send messages to the kings of Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, and Sidon, with messengers who have come to King Zedekiah of Judah in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give them an order for their masters: “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Say this to your masters,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I used my great strength and my powerful arm to make the earth along with the people and the animals on it. I give it to anyone I please.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I have handed all these countries over to my servant King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. I have even made wild animals serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All nations will serve him, his son, and his grandson until Babylon is defeated. Then many nations and great kings will make him their slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Suppose nations or kingdoms won’t serve or surrender to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. I will punish those nations by wars, famines, and plagues, until I have put an end to them by Nebuchadnezzar’s power, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t listen to prophets, mediums, interpreters of dreams, fortunetellers, or sorcerers who tell you that you’ll never serve the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are prophesying lies to you. They will cause you to be taken far from your lands. I’ll scatter you, and you will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But suppose a nation surrenders to the king of Babylon and serves him. I will let it stay in its own land. People will farm the land and live on it,’ ” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I spoke the same message to King Zedekiah of Judah, “Surrender to the king of Babylon, serve him and his people, and you will stay alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should you and your people die in wars, famines, and plagues? The Lord has threatened the nations that don’t serve the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t listen to the prophets who tell you that you’ll never serve the king of Babylon. They are prophesying lies to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I didn’t send them, declares the Lord. They prophesy lies in my name. So I will scatter you, and you and the prophets will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I also spoke this message to the priests and all the people. “This is what the Lord said to me: Don’t listen to the prophets who tell you that the utensils of the Lord’s temple will be brought back from Babylon soon. They are prophesying lies to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t listen to them. Instead, serve the king of Babylon, and live. Why should this city be turned into rubble?
speaker: Narrator

text: If they are prophets and the Lord is speaking to them, they should beg the Lord of Armies not to allow the utensils that are left in the Lord’s temple, in the royal palace of Judah, and in Jerusalem to be taken away to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: -“Babylon’s King Nebuchadnezzar took Jehoiakin, son of King Jehoiakim of Judah, into captivity from Jerusalem to Babylon along with all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem. But he didn’t take the pillars, the bronze pool, the stands, and the rest of the utensils that are left in this city.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says about the utensils that are left in the Lord’s temple, in the royal palace of Judah, and in Jerusalem:
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be taken to Babylon and stay there until I come for them, declares the Lord. I will take them from there and bring them back to this place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that same year, early in the rule of King Zedekiah of Judah, in the fifth month of his fourth year as king, the prophet Hananiah, son of Azzur, from Gibeon, spoke to me in the Lord’s temple. He said to me in front of the priests and all the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I will break the yoke  of the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within two years I will bring back all the utensils of the Lord’s temple that King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon took from this place and carried off to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will also bring back to this place Jehoiakin, son of King Jehoiakim of Judah, and all the captives of Judah who went to Babylon, declares the Lord. So I will break the yoke of the king of Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Jeremiah replied to the prophet Hananiah in front of the priests and all the people standing in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Amen! May the Lord do this! May the Lord make your prophecy come true and bring back the utensils of the Lord’s temple and all the captives from Babylon to this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now listen to this message that I am speaking to you and to all the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: Long ago, the prophets who preceded you and me prophesied wars, disasters, and plagues against many countries and great kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the prophet who prophesied peace was recognized as a prophet that the Lord sent only if the message of the prophet came true.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet Hananiah took the yoke off the neck of the prophet Jeremiah and broke it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hananiah said in front of all the people, “This is what the Lord says: In the same way, I will break the yoke of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon off the neck of all the nations within two years.” Then the prophet Jeremiah went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the prophet Hananiah broke the yoke off the neck of the prophet Jeremiah, the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Hananiah, ‘This is what the Lord says: You have broken the wooden yoke, but I  will replace it with an iron yoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I will put an iron yoke on the necks of all these nations so that they will serve King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. They will serve him! I will even make wild animals serve him.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah told the prophet Hananiah, “Now listen, Hananiah, the Lord hasn’t sent you. You have made these people believe a lie.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: I’m going to remove you from the face of the earth. You will die this year because you have encouraged rebellion against the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prophet Hananiah died in the seventh month of that year.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Jeremiah sent a letter from Jerusalem to the rest of the leaders among the captives. He also sent it to the priests, the prophets, and all the people that Nebuchadnezzar took away as captives from Jerusalem to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: (This was after King Jehoiakin  and his mother, the court officials, the leaders of Judah and Jerusalem, the craftsmen, and metal workers left Jerusalem.)
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent the letter with Shaphan’s son Elasah and Hilkiah’s son Gemariah, whom King Zedekiah of Judah had sent to King Nebuchadnezzar in Babylon. The letter said:
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says to all those who were taken captive from Jerusalem to Babylon:
speaker: Narrator

text: Build houses, and live in them. Plant gardens, and eat what they produce.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get married, and have sons and daughters. Find wives for your sons, and let your daughters get married so that they can have sons and daughters. Grow in number there; don’t decrease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Work for the good of the city where I’ve taken you as captives, and pray to the Lord for that city. When it prospers, you will also prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Don’t let the prophets or the mediums who are among you trick you. Don’t even listen to your own dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text: These people are prophesying lies to you in my name. I didn’t send them, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: When Babylon’s 70 years are over, I will come to you. I will keep my promise to you and bring you back to this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know the plans that I have for you, declares the Lord. They are plans for peace and not disaster, plans to give you a future filled with hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will call to me. You will come and pray to me, and I will hear you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you look for me, you will find me. When you wholeheartedly seek me,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will let you find me, declares the Lord. I will bring you back from captivity. I will gather you from all the nations and places where I’ve scattered you, declares the Lord. I will bring you back from the place where you are being held captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ve said that the Lord has given you prophets in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this is what the Lord says about the king who sits on David’s throne and about all the people who live in this city, the people who are your relatives and who weren’t taken away as captives:
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of Armies says: I’m going to send them wars, famines, and plagues. These people are like rotten figs to me, figs that are so bad that they can’t be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will chase them with wars, famines, and plagues. I will make them a horrifying sight to all the kingdoms on the earth. They will become something cursed, ridiculed, and hissed at, and they will be a disgrace among all the nations where I scatter them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They didn’t listen to me, declares the Lord. I sent them my servants the prophets again and again, but they refused to listen, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So listen to the Lord’s word, all you captives who were sent away from Jerusalem to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says about Kolaiah’s son Ahab and about Maaseiah’s son Zedekiah, who prophesy lies to you in my name: I’m going to hand them over to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. I will kill them as you watch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of them, all the captives from Judah who are in Babylon will use this curse: May the Lord curse you as he cursed Zedekiah and Ahab, whom the king of Babylon burned to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have done shameful things in Israel. They committed adultery with their neighbors’ wives and spoke lies in my name. I didn’t command them to do this. I know what they have done. I’m a witness, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord says, “Say to Shemaiah from Nehelam,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: You sent letters in your own name to all the people who are in Jerusalem, to the priest Zephaniah, son of Maaseiah, and to all the priests. These letters said:
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made you priest instead of Jehoiada so that there would be officials for the Lord’s temple. You should put any lunatic who acts like a prophet in prison and in shackles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, why haven’t you arrested Jeremiah from Anathoth? After all, he acts like a prophet among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why Jeremiah sent this message to us in Babylon: You will be captives a long time. Build houses, and live in them. Plant gardens, and eat what they produce.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest Zephaniah read this letter to the prophet Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Send this message to all the captives: ‘This is what the Lord says about Shemaiah from Nehelam: Shemaiah prophesied to you, but I didn’t send him. He has made you believe a lie.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord says: I will punish Shemaiah from Nehelam. I will also punish his descendants. No one from his family will be left alive. He will not see the blessings that I’m going to send my people, declares the Lord, because he has encouraged rebellion against the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Write in a book everything that I tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I will bring my people Israel and Judah back from captivity. I will bring them back to the land that I gave their ancestors, and they will take possession of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the message that the Lord spoke about Israel and Judah:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord says:
“We hear cries of fear, cries of panic, not cries of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ask now, and see: Can a man give birth to a child?
Why, then, do I see every strong man holding his stomach in pain
like a woman giving birth to a child?
Why has every face turned pale?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How terrible that day will be!
There will be no other day like it.
It will be a time of calamity for the descendants of Jacob,
but they will be rescued from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that day,” declares the Lord of Armies, “I will break the yokes  off your necks and tear off your ropes. Foreigners will no longer make you serve them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will serve the Lord your God and David your king. I will establish him for you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Don’t be afraid, my servant Jacob,” declares the Lord.
“Don’t be terrified, Israel.
I’m going to rescue you from a faraway place.
I’m going to rescue your descendants from where they are captives.
The descendants of Jacob will again have peace and security,
and no one will frighten them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am with you, and I will rescue you,” declares the Lord.
“I will completely destroy all the nations where I scattered you,
but I will not completely destroy you.
I will correct you with justice.
I won’t let you go entirely unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord says:
Your wound is incurable.
Your injury is beyond healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one argues that you should be healed.
No medicine will heal you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All your lovers have forgotten you,
and they don’t want you anymore.
I’ve punished you as an enemy would.
I’ve corrected you as a cruel person would.
You are very wicked, and you have many sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you cry about your wound, your injury that can’t be cured?
I’ve done this to you.
You are very wicked, and you have many sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why everyone who devours you will be devoured,
and all your enemies will be taken away as captives.
Those who looted you will be looted.
Those who stole from you in war will have things stolen from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll restore your health and heal your wounds,” declares the Lord.
“People call you an outcast:
Zion, no one cares for you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord says:
I’m going to bring the captives back to Jacob’s tents
and show compassion on their homes.
Cities will be built on the ruins,
and fortified palaces will be built in their rightful place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people who live there will sing songs of praise,
and the sound of laughter will be heard from there.
I’ll make them numerous, and their number won’t decrease.
I’ll bring them honor, and they won’t be considered unimportant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their children will be like they were long ago.
Their community will be established in my presence,
and I will punish everyone who oppresses them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their leader will be someone from their own people.
Their ruler will come from among them.
I’ll bring him near, and he will come close to me.
Who would dare to come near me?” asks the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be my people, and I will be your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The storm of the Lord will come with his anger.
Like a driving wind, it will swirl down on the heads of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord’s burning anger will not turn back
until he has done everything he intends to do.
In the last days you will understand this clearly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time,” declares the Lord, “I will be the God of all the families of Israel, and they will be my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
The people who survived the wars have found favor in the desert.
Israel went to find its rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord appeared to me in a faraway place and said,
“I love you with an everlasting love.
So I will continue to show you my kindness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once again I will build you up,
and you will be rebuilt, my dear people Israel.
Once again you will take your tambourines,
and you will go dancing with happy people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once again you will plant vineyards on the mountains of Samaria.
Those who plant them will enjoy the fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There will be a day when watchmen on the mountains of Ephraim
will call out this message:
‘Arise! Let’s go to Zion, to the Lord our God.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
Sing a happy song about Jacob.
Sing joyfully for the leader of the nations.
Shout, sing praise, and say,
“O Lord, rescue your people, the remaining few from Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will bring them from the land of the north.
I will gather them from the farthest parts of the earth.
Blind people and lame people will return
together with pregnant women and those in labor.
A large crowd will return here.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will cry as they return.
They will pray as I bring them back.
I will lead them beside streams
on a level path where they will not stumble.
I will be a Father to Israel,
and Ephraim will be my firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You nations, listen to the Lord’s word.
Tell it to the distant islands.
Say, ‘The one who scattered the people of Israel will gather them
and watch over them as a shepherd watches over his flock.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will free the descendants of Jacob
and reclaim them from those who are stronger than they are.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will come and shout for joy on top of Mount Zion.
They will stream to it to enjoy the Lord’s blessings:
fresh grain, new wine, and olive oil, lambs and calves.
Their lives will be like well-watered gardens,
and they will never suffer again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then young women will rejoice and dance
along with young men and old men.
I will turn their mourning into joy.
I will comfort them.
I will give them joy in place of their sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will satisfy the priests with rich food.
My people will be filled with my blessings,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
A sound is heard in Ramah,
the sound of crying in bitter grief.
Rachel is crying for her children.
She refuses to be comforted,
because they are dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
Stop your crying, and wipe away your tears.
You will be rewarded for your work, declares the Lord.
You will return from the land of the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your future is filled with hope, declares the Lord.
Your children will return to their own territory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have certainly heard Ephraim mourn and say,
‘You disciplined me, and I was disciplined.
I was like a young, untrained calf.
Turn me, and I will be turned,
because you are the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After I was turned around, I changed the way I thought and acted.
After I was taught a lesson, I hung my head in shame.
I was so ashamed and humiliated,
because of all the stupid things I have done
ever since I was young.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is Ephraim my dear son? Is he a pleasant child?
Even though I have often spoken against him, I still think fondly of him.
That is why my heart longs for him,
and I will certainly have compassion on him,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Set up landmarks!
Put up road signs!
Remember the highway, the road on which you traveled.
Come back, my dear people Israel, come back to your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long will you wander around, you unfaithful people?
The Lord will create something new on earth:
A woman will protect a man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: When I have brought them back from captivity, they will once again use this saying in Judah and in its cities:
“The Lord bless you, home of righteousness, holy mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah and all its cities will live there together.
Farmers and shepherds will also live there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will give those who are weary all they need.
I will refresh everyone who is filled with sorrow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, I woke up and looked around. My sleep had been pleasant.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I will plant the nations of Israel and Judah with people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once I watched over them to uproot them, to tear them down, and to wreck, ruin, and hurt them. Now I will watch over them to build them up and to plant them,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When those days come, people will no longer say, ‘Fathers have eaten sour grapes, and their children’s teeth are set on edge.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But each person will die for his own sin. Whoever eats sour grapes will have his own teeth set on edge.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I will make a new promise  to Israel and Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will not be like the promise that I made to their ancestors when I took them by the hand and brought them out of Egypt. They rejected that promise, although I was a husband to them,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But this is the promise that I will make to Israel after those days,” declares the Lord: “I will put my teachings inside them, and I will write those teachings on their hearts. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer will each person teach his neighbors or his relatives by saying, ‘Know the Lord.’ All of them, from the least important to the most important, will know me,” declares the Lord, “because I will forgive their wickedness and I will no longer hold their sins against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord provides the sun to be a light during the day.
He orders the moon and stars to be lights during the night.
He stirs up the sea so that its waves roar.
His name is the Lord of Armies.
This is what the Lord says:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Only if these laws stop working, declares the Lord,
will Israel’s descendants stop being a nation in my presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
Only if the heavens could be measured
or the foundations of the earth could be searched,
would I ever reject all of Israel’s descendants
because of everything that they have done, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when the city will be rebuilt for me from the Tower of Hananel to Corner Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: A measuring line will stretch from there straight to the Hill of Gareb, and then it will turn to Goah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole valley, filled with its dead bodies and ashes, and the whole area to the Kidron Valley, as far as the corner of Horse Gate in the east, will be holy to the Lord. It will never be uprooted or torn down again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah during Zedekiah’s tenth year as king of Judah. (This was Nebuchadnezzar’s eighteenth year as king.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that time the army of the king of Babylon was blockading Jerusalem.
The prophet Jeremiah was locked up in the courtyard of the prison. This prison was in the palace of the king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Zedekiah of Judah locked up Jeremiah, Zedekiah asked him, “Why are you prophesying? You are saying, ‘This is what the Lord says: I’m going to hand this city over to the king of Babylon, and he will capture it.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Zedekiah of Judah will not escape from the Babylonians. He will certainly be handed over to the king of Babylon. He will talk to Nebuchadnezzar in person and look him in the eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar will take Zedekiah to Babylon, and Zedekiah will stay there until I deal with him, declares the Lord. When you fight the Babylonians, you won’t win.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah said, “The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Jeremiah, your cousin Hanamel, son of Shallum, is going to come to you and say, “Buy my field that is in Anathoth, because as the closest relative it is your responsibility to buy it.” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then, as the Lord had said, my cousin Hanamel came to me in the courtyard of the prison. He said to me, ‘Please buy my field that is in Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin. It is your responsibility to purchase it, because the rights of the closest relative belong to you. Buy it for yourself.’ Then I knew that the Lord had spoken to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I bought the field in Anathoth from my cousin Hanamel and gave him the money. The field cost seven ounces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: I signed the deed, sealed it, had people witness the signing of the deed, and paid out the silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I took the sealed copy of the deed, containing the terms and conditions, as well as an unsealed copy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave the copies of the deeds to Baruch, son of Neriah and grandson of Mahseiah. I did this in the presence of my cousin Hanamel and the witnesses who had signed the deed and in the presence of all the Jews who were sitting in the courtyard of the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I gave Baruch these orders:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Take both of these documents, both the sealed and the unsealed copies of the deed. Put them in a clay jar so that they will last a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: My people will again buy houses, fields, and vineyards in this land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “After I had given the copies to Baruch, son of Neriah, I prayed to the Lord. I prayed,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Almighty Lord, you made heaven and earth by your great strength and powerful arm. Nothing is too hard for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You show mercy to thousands of generations. However, you punish children for the wickedness of their parents. You, God, are great and mighty. Your name is the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You make wise plans and do mighty things. You see everything the descendants of Adam do. You reward them for the way they live and for what they do.
speaker: Narrator

text: You performed miraculous signs and amazing things in Egypt. To this day you are still doing them in Israel. You made a name for yourself that continues to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You brought your people from Egypt with miraculous signs and amazing things, with a mighty hand and a powerful arm, and with great terror.
speaker: Narrator

text: You gave them the land that you swore with an oath to give their ancestors, the land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: They entered and took possession of it. However, they refused to obey you or to follow your teachings. They didn’t do anything you commanded them to do, so you brought all this disaster on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘See how the dirt ramps have been built up around the city to capture it! Because of wars, famines, and plagues, the city will be handed over to the Babylonians who are attacking it. What you have threatened to do has happened, as you can see.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you, Almighty Lord, told me to buy a field with money and get witnesses to confirm it, although the city was handed over to the Babylonians.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the Lord God of all humanity. Nothing is too hard for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: I’m going to hand this city over to the Babylonians and King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. They will capture it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Babylonians who are attacking this city will break in, set this city on fire, and burn it down. They will burn down the houses of people who made me furious by going up to the roofs to burn incense to Baal and to pour out wine offerings to other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ever since they were young, the people of Israel and Judah have done what I consider evil. The people of Israel have made me furious by what they’ve done,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The people in this city have made me so angry and furious from the day they built it to this day. So now I must remove this city from my presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The people of Israel and Judah have made me furious because they are evil. The people, their kings and officials, their priests and prophets, and the Judeans and those who live in Jerusalem
speaker: Narrator

text: have turned their backs, not their faces to me. I taught them again and again, but they refused to listen and learn.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set up their detestable idols in the temple that is called by my name, and they dishonored it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the valley of Ben Hinnom they built worship sites for Baal to sacrifice their sons and daughters to Molech. I didn’t ask them to do this. It never entered my mind. I didn’t make Judah sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have said this about the city, ‘Because of wars, famines, and plagues it will be handed over to the king of Babylon.’ Now this is what the Lord God of Israel says:
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to gather the people from all the lands where I scattered them in my anger, fury, and terrifying wrath. I will bring them back to this place and make them live here securely.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be my people, and I will be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give them the same attitude and the same purpose so that they will fear me as long as they live. This will be for their own good and for the good of their children.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make an eternal promise  to them that I will never stop blessing them. I will make them fear me so that they will never turn away from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will enjoy blessing them. With all my heart and soul I will faithfully plant them in this land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: As I brought all these disasters on these people, so I will bring on them all these blessings that I have promised them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have said that this land is a wasteland, without people or animals living in it. You have also said that it has been handed over to the Babylonians. But people will once again buy fields in this land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will buy fields for money, sign deeds, seal them, and have people witness the signing of the deeds. This will happen in the territory of Benjamin, in the region of Jerusalem, in the cities of Judah, in the cities on the mountains, in the hill country, and in the Negev because I will bring them back from their captivity,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jeremiah was still being held in the courtyard of the prison, the Lord spoke his word to him a second time. The Lord said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I made the earth, formed it, and set it in place. My name is the Lord. This is what the Lord says:
speaker: Narrator

text: Call to me, and I will answer you. I will tell you great and mysterious things that you do not know.
speaker: Narrator

text: The houses in this city and the palaces of the kings of Judah have been torn down to be used against the dirt ramps and weapons of the Babylonians. This is what the Lord God of Israel says about this:
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel fought the Babylonians. Now their houses are filled with the bodies of their own people I killed in my anger and my fury. I will hide my face from this city because of its wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I will heal this city and restore it to health. I will heal its people, and I will give them peace and security.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will restore Judah and Israel and rebuild them as they were before.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cleanse them from all the sins that they have committed against me. I will forgive them for all the sins that they have committed against me and for rebelling against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jerusalem will be my source of joy, praise, and honor. All the nations on earth will hear about all the blessings that I will give to Jerusalem. They will be afraid and tremble because of all the prosperity that I will provide for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: You have said that this place is ruined and that no people or animals live in it. It’s true! The cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem are deserted. No people or animals live there. But once again you will hear
speaker: Narrator

text:
the sounds of joy and happiness and the sounds of brides and grooms. You will hear those who bring thank offerings to the Lord’s temple say,
‘Give thanks to the Lord of Armies because the Lord is good,
because his mercy endures forever.’
I will restore the fortunes of the land to what they were before,” says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies says: In this deserted place, where no people or animals live, and in all its cities, there will once again be pastures where shepherds can rest their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the cities on the mountains, in the foothills, in the Negev, in the territory of Benjamin, in the area around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, shepherds will once again count their sheep,” says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I will keep the promise that I made to Israel and Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days and at that time, I will cause a righteous branch to spring up for David. He will do what is fair and right in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Judah will be saved and Jerusalem will live securely. Jerusalem will be called The Lord Our Righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This what the Lord says: David will never fail to have a descendant sitting on the throne of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levitical priests will never fail to have a descendant in my presence to sacrifice burnt offerings, to burn grain offerings, and to prepare daily sacrifices.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: Suppose you could break my arrangement  with day and night so that they wouldn’t come at their proper time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then my arrangement with my servant David could be broken, and he would not have a descendant to rule on his throne. The arrangement with my servants the Levitical priests could also be broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will multiply the descendants of my servant David and the Levites who serve me like the stars of heaven that cannot be counted and the sand on the seashore that cannot be measured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Haven’t you noticed what these people have said? They have said that the Lord has rejected the two families he has chosen. They despise my people, and they no longer consider them a nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: Suppose I hadn’t made an arrangement with day and night or made laws for heaven and earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I would reject the descendants of Jacob and of my servant David. I would not let any of David’s descendants rule the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. However, I will restore their fortunes and love them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah when King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, his entire army, and all the kingdoms and people that he ruled were attacking Jerusalem and all its cities. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Go to King Zedekiah of Judah, and tell him, ‘The Lord says: I’m going to hand this city over to the king of Babylon, and he will burn it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not escape from him. You will certainly be captured and handed over to him. You will see the king of Babylon with your own eyes, and he will talk to you face to face. Then you will go to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Listen to the Lord’s word, King Zedekiah of Judah. This is what the Lord says about you: You will not die in war.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die peacefully. People will burn funeral fires for you as they did for your ancestors, the kings who lived before you. They will say, “Oh, master,” as they mourn for you. I have spoken my word, declares the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Jeremiah told all these things to King Zedekiah of Judah in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this when the army of the king of Babylon was attacking Jerusalem and the cities of Lachish and Azekah. These were the only fortified cities of Judah that were left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah after King Zedekiah and all the people in Jerusalem promised to free their slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone was supposed to free his Hebrew slaves, both male and female. No one was supposed to keep another Jew as a slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the officials and all the people agreed and promised to free their male and female slaves and not to keep them as slaves anymore. So they set them free.
speaker: Narrator

text: But afterwards, they changed their minds and took back the men and women they had freed and made them their slaves again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: I put a condition on the promise  I made to your ancestors when I brought them from Egypt, where they were slaves. I said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Every seven years each of you must free any Hebrews who sold themselves to you. When they have served you for six years, you must set them free.’ But your ancestors refused to obey me or listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Recently, you changed and did what I consider right. You agreed to free your neighbors, and you made a promise in my presence, in the temple that is called by my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you have changed again and dishonored me. You brought back the male and female slaves that you had set free to live their own lives. You have forced them to be your male and female slaves again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: You didn’t obey me. You haven’t freed your relatives and neighbors. Now I am going to free you,” declares the Lord. “I will free you to die in wars, plagues, and famines. I will make all the kingdoms of the world horrified at the thought of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand over the people who have rejected my promise. They have not kept the terms of the promise which they made in my presence when they cut a calf in two and passed between its pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand over the officials of Judah and Jerusalem, the palace officials, the priests, and all the common people who passed between the pieces of the calf.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand them over to their enemies who want to kill them, and their corpses will be food for birds and wild animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand King Zedekiah of Judah and his officials over to their enemies who want to kill them and to the army of the king of Babylon, the army that has withdrawn from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to give a command,” declares the Lord. “I will bring that army back to this city to attack it, capture it, and burn it down. I will destroy the cities of Judah so that no one will live there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah during the reign of Jehoiakim, son of King Josiah of Judah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go to the family of Rechab and talk to them. Take them into one of the side rooms in the Lord’s temple, and offer them a drink of wine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I took Jaazaniah, who was the son of Jeremiah and the grandson of Habazziniah, and I took Jaazaniah’s brothers and all his sons—the whole family of Rechab.
speaker: Narrator

text: I brought them into the Lord’s temple, into the side room of the sons of Hanan. (He was Igdaliah’s son, the man of God.) It was next to the room of the officials and above the side room of Maaseiah, Shallum’s son, the doorkeeper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I set cups and pitchers filled with wine in front of the family of Rechab. I said to them, “Drink some wine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered, “We don’t drink wine, because our ancestor Jonadab, Rechab’s son, gave us this order: ‘You and your descendants must never drink wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never build any houses or plant any fields or vineyards. You must never have any of these things. You must always live in tents so that you may live for a long time in the land where you are staying.’
speaker: Narrator

text: We, along with our wives, sons, and daughters, have obeyed our ancestor Jonadab, Rechab’s son, in everything he ordered us to do. We have never drunk wine,
speaker: Narrator

text: built houses to live in, or owned vineyards, pastures, or grainfields.
speaker: Narrator

text: We live in tents, and we have obeyed everything our ancestor Jonadab ordered us to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon invaded this land, we said, ‘Let’s go to Jerusalem to escape the Babylonian and Aramean armies.’ That’s why we are living in Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Tell the people of Judah and those who live in Jerusalem, ‘Won’t you ever learn your lesson and obey my words? declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonadab, Rechab’s son, ordered his descendants not to drink wine. This order has been carried out. His descendants have not drunk any wine to this day, because they have obeyed their ancestor’s order. I have spoken to you again and again, but you have refused to listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have sent all my servants the prophets to you again and again. They said, “Turn from your evil ways, do what is right, and don’t follow other gods in order to serve them. Then you will live in the land that I gave you and your ancestors.” However, you refused to listen to me or obey me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Jonadab, Rechab’s son, have carried out the orders of their ancestor, but you refuse to listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Lord God of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I am going to bring on Judah and on all those who live in Jerusalem all the disasters that I threatened. I have spoken to them, but they didn’t listen. I called to them, but they didn’t answer.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah said to the family of Rechab, “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: You obeyed the order of your ancestor Jonadab, followed all his instructions, and did exactly what he told you to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: A descendant of Jonadab, Rechab’s son, will always serve me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim, son of King Josiah of Judah, the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a scroll, and write on it everything that I have dictated to you about Israel, Judah, and all the other nations from the time I spoke to you during the reign of Josiah until today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maybe the nation of Judah will hear about all the disasters that I plan to bring on them, and they will turn from their wicked ways. Then I will forgive their wickedness and their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah called Baruch, son of Neriah. Jeremiah dictated everything that the Lord had told him, and Baruch wrote it all down on a scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah told Baruch, “I’m no longer allowed to go to the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: On a day of fasting, you must read from the scroll the Lord’s message that you wrote as I dictated. You must read it to the people in the Lord’s temple. You must also read it to all the people of Judah when they come from their cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maybe their prayers will come into the Lord’s presence, and they will turn from their evil ways. The Lord has threatened these people with his terrifying anger and fury.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Baruch, son of Neriah, did as the prophet Jeremiah commanded him. In the Lord’s temple he read from the scroll everything that the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the ninth month of the fifth year of the reign of Jehoiakim, son of King Josiah of Judah, a time for fasting was called. It was a time for all the people in Jerusalem and for everyone who was coming from any city in Judah to Jerusalem to fast in the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Baruch read the scroll containing Jeremiah’s words. Baruch read it to all the people in the Lord’s temple in the room of the scribe Gemariah, son of Shaphan, in the upper courtyard at the entrance of New Gate of the Lord’s temple.
