speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah, who was the son of Gemariah and the grandson of Shaphan, heard Baruch read from the scroll everything the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went down to the scribe’s room in the king’s palace where all the scribes were sitting. The scribe Elishama, Delaiah (son of Shemaiah), Elnathan (son of Achbor), Gemariah (son of Shaphan), Zedekiah (son of Hananiah), and all the other officials were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah told them everything he heard Baruch read from the scroll publicly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the officials sent Jehudi, who was the son of Nethaniah, the grandson of Shelemiah, and the great-grandson of Cushi, to Baruch. Jehudi said to Baruch, “Bring the scroll that you read publicly, and come with me.” Baruch, son of Neriah, took the scroll and went with him to see the officers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to Baruch, “Please sit down, and read it to us.”
So Baruch read it to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard everything, they turned to each other in terror. They said to Baruch, “We must tell the king everything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they asked Baruch, “Please tell us how you wrote all this. Did Jeremiah dictate it to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Baruch answered, “He dictated everything to me, and I wrote it on the scroll in ink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials said to Baruch, “You and Jeremiah must hide. Don’t let anyone know where you are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After they put the scroll in the side room of the scribe Elishama, they went to the king in the courtyard and told him everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent Jehudi to get the scroll. He took the scroll from the side room of the scribe Elishama. Jehudi read it to the king and all the officials standing by the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the ninth month, and the king was in his winter house sitting in front of the fire in the fireplace.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jehudi read three or four columns, the king would cut them off with a scribe’s knife and throw them into the fire in the fireplace. He did this until the whole scroll was burned up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and all his attendants didn’t show any fear or tear their clothes in fear when they heard everything being read.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah urged the king not to burn the scroll, he refused to listen to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded Jerahmeel (the king’s son), Seraiah (son of Azriel), and Shelemiah (son of Abdeel) to arrest the scribe Baruch and the prophet Jeremiah. But the Lord had hidden Baruch and Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the king burned up the scroll that Baruch had written and that Jeremiah had dictated, the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take another scroll, and write on it everything that was written on the scroll that King Jehoiakim of Judah burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say about King Jehoiakim of Judah, ‘This is what the Lord says: You burned this scroll, and you asked Jeremiah, “Why did you write that the king of Babylon will certainly come to destroy this land and take away people and animals?”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says about King Jehoiakim of Judah: He will have no one to sit on David’s throne, and his own corpse will be thrown out and exposed to the heat of day and the cold of night.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish him, his descendants, and his attendants for their wickedness. They refused to listen. So I will bring on them, on those who live in Jerusalem, and on the people of Judah all the disasters that I have threatened.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to the scribe Baruch, son of Neriah. As Jeremiah dictated, Baruch wrote on it everything that was on the scroll that King Jehoiakim of Judah had burned. They added many similar messages.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon appointed Zedekiah, son of Josiah, to be king of Judah. Zedekiah succeeded Jehoiakin, son of Jehoiakim.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zedekiah, his administrators, and the common people didn’t listen to what the Lord had spoken through the prophet Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Zedekiah sent Jehucal (son of Shelemiah) and the priest Zephaniah (son of Maaseiah) to the prophet Jeremiah. They asked him, “Please pray to the Lord our God for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah was still free to come and go among the people. The people of Jerusalem hadn’t put him in prison yet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s army had come from Egypt, and when the Babylonians who were blockading Jerusalem heard this news, they retreated from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to the prophet Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Say this to the king of Judah, who sent you to get advice from me: ‘Pharaoh’s army has come out to help you. But it will go back to Egypt, its own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Babylonians will return. They will attack the city, capture it, and burn it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Lord says: Don’t deceive yourselves by thinking that the Babylonians will leave you. They will not leave you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if you would defeat the entire Babylonian army so that they had only a few badly wounded men left in their tents, they would get up and burn down this city.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonian army had retreated from Jerusalem because Pharaoh’s army was coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jeremiah wanted to leave Jerusalem and go to the territory of Benjamin to take possession of his property there among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when he came to Benjamin Gate, the captain of the guard there, whose name was Irijah, son of Shelemiah and grandson of Hananiah, arrested the prophet Jeremiah. He said, “You’re deserting to the Babylonians!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah answered, “That’s a lie! I’m not deserting to the Babylonians.” But Irijah wouldn’t listen to him. Irijah arrested Jeremiah and took him to the officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials were so angry with Jeremiah that they beat him and put him in prison in the scribe Jonathan’s house, which had been turned into a prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah went into a prison cell, and he stayed there a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah, and the king asked him privately in the palace, “Is there any message from the Lord?”
Jeremiah answered, “Yes! There is a message from the Lord. You will be handed over to the king of Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah asked King Zedekiah, “What crime have I committed against you, your administrators, or these people? Why have you put me in prison?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are the prophets who told you that the king of Babylon wouldn’t attack you and this land?
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, Your Majesty, please listen, and accept my plea for mercy. Don’t return me to the scribe Jonathan’s house, or I will die there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Zedekiah gave the command to have Jeremiah put in the courtyard of the prison. He gave him a loaf of bread every day from the bakers’ street until all the bread in the city was gone. So Jeremiah stayed in the courtyard of the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shephatiah (son of Mattan), Gedaliah (son of Pashhur), Jucal (son of Shelemiah), and Pashhur (son of Malchiah) heard that Jeremiah was speaking to all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They heard Jeremiah say, “This is what the Lord says: Those who stay in this city will die in wars, famines, or plagues. But those who surrender to the Babylonians will live. They will escape with their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: This city will certainly be handed over to the army of the king of Babylon, and it will capture the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the officials said to the king, “Have this man put to death. He discourages the soldiers who are left in this city and all the people by telling them such things. This man is not trying to help these people; he’s trying to hurt them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Zedekiah answered, “He’s in your hands. I won’t do anything to stop you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took Jeremiah and threw him into the cistern of Malchiah, the king’s son. It was in the courtyard of the prison. They used ropes to lower Jeremiah into the cistern. There was no water in the cistern, only mud, and Jeremiah sank in the mud.
speaker: Narrator

text: But an official in the royal palace, Ebed Melech from Sudan, heard that they had put Jeremiah in the cistern. The king happened to be sitting at Benjamin Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ebed Melech left the royal palace and spoke to the king at Benjamin Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your Majesty, everything that these men have done to the prophet Jeremiah is wrong. They have thrown him into the cistern, where he’ll starve to death, because there’s no more bread in the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king gave Ebed Melech from Sudan this command: “Take 30 men from here, and lift the prophet Jeremiah out of the cistern before he dies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ebed Melech took the men with him and went to the royal palace, to a room under the treasury. He took rags and torn clothes from there and lowered them with ropes to Jeremiah in the cistern.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ebed Melech from Sudan said to Jeremiah, “Put these rags and torn clothes under your arms to protect you from the ropes.” Jeremiah did.
speaker: Narrator

text: They used the ropes to pull Jeremiah up and lift him out of the cistern. Then Jeremiah stayed in the courtyard of the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Zedekiah sent for the prophet Jeremiah and brought him to the third entrance in the Lord’s temple. “I’m going to ask you a question,” the king said to Jeremiah. “Don’t hide anything from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah answered Zedekiah, “If I answer you, you’ll kill me. If I give you advice, you won’t listen to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Zedekiah secretly swore an oath to Jeremiah, “The Lord gave us life. As the Lord lives, I will not kill you or hand you over to these men who want to kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “This is what the Lord God of Armies, the God of Israel, says: If you surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, you will live, and this city will not be burned. You and your household will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, this city will be handed over to the Babylonians. They will burn it down, and you will not escape from them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Zedekiah answered Jeremiah, “I’m afraid of the Jews who have deserted to the Babylonians. The Babylonians may hand me over to them, and they will torture me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah said, “You will not be handed over to them. Obey the Lord by doing what I’m telling you. Then everything will go well for you, and you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refuse to surrender, this is what the Lord has shown me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the women who are left in the palace of Judah’s king will be brought out to the officers of the king of Babylon. These women will say:
‘Your trusted friends have misled you and used you.
Your feet are stuck in the mud, and your friends have deserted you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “All your wives and children will be brought to the Babylonians. You will not escape from them. You will be captured by the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “Don’t let anyone know about this conversation, or you will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials may find out that I’ve been talking with you. They may come to you and say, ‘Tell us what you said to the king and what the king said to you. Don’t hide anything from us, or we’ll kill you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If they come to you, say to them, ‘I asked the king not to send me back to Jonathan’s house to die there.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the officials came to Jeremiah and questioned him. He told them exactly what the king had told him to say. So they stopped questioning him, because they hadn’t heard his conversation with the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah stayed in the courtyard of the prison until the day Jerusalem was captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the tenth month of Zedekiah’s ninth year as king of Judah, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked Jerusalem with his entire army and blockaded it.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ninth day of the fourth month of Zedekiah’s eleventh year as king, they broke into the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the officers of the king of Babylon came in and sat in Middle Gate: Nergal (the quartermaster), Samgar Nebo (the chief officer), Nergal (the quartermaster and the chief fortuneteller), and all the rest of the officers of the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Zedekiah of Judah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled. They left the city at night by way of the king’s garden through the gate between the two walls, and they took the road to the plain of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonian army pursued them and caught up with Zedekiah in the plain of Jericho. They arrested him and brought him to Babylon’s King Nebuchadnezzar at Riblah in the territory of Hamath. The king of Babylon passed sentence on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons as Zedekiah watched at Riblah. He also slaughtered all the leaders of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he blinded Zedekiah, put him in bronze shackles, and took him to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonians burned down the royal palace and the people’s homes, and they tore down the walls of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan, Babylon’s captain of the guard, captured the few people left in the city, those who surrendered to him, and the rest of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, left some poor people who had nothing in the land of Judah. At that time he gave them vineyards and farms.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon gave Nebuzaradan an order concerning Jeremiah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take him, and look after him. Don’t harm him in any way, but do for him whatever he asks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan (the captain of the guard), Nebushazban (the chief official), Nergal (the quartermaster and the chief fortuneteller), and all the other leaders of the king of Babylon sent for Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took Jeremiah out of the courtyard of the prison and handed him over to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, to take him home. So he lived among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jeremiah was still confined in the courtyard of the prison, the Lord spoke his word to him. The Lord said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to Ebed Melech from Sudan, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I’m going to carry out my threat against this city by bringing disaster on it instead of prosperity. At that time these things will happen as you watch.
speaker: Narrator

text: But at that time I will rescue you, declares the Lord. You will not be handed over to those you fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will certainly rescue you. You will not die in war. You will escape with your life because you trusted me, declares the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah after Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, let him go at Ramah. Nebuzaradan found Jeremiah in chains along with the captives of Jerusalem and Judah who were being taken to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard took Jeremiah aside and said to him, “The Lord your God threatened to bring this disaster on this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has carried out his threat. The Lord did as he promised because you Israelites have sinned against him and refused to obey him. That is why this has happened to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today I’m removing the chains from your hands. If you would like to come with me to Babylon, come, and I’ll look after you. But if you don’t want to come with me to Babylon, don’t come. The whole land is yours. Go wherever you want.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you wish to remain, then go back to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon appointed to govern the cities of Judah. Live among the people with him, or go anywhere you want.” The captain of the guard gave Jeremiah some food and a present and let him go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah went to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, at Mizpah and lived with him among the people who were left in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the army commanders and their men who were in the field heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, to govern the country and some of the country’s poorest men, women, and children who had not been taken away to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the commanders who went with their men to Gedaliah at Mizpah: Ishmael (son of Nethaniah), Johanan and Jonathan (sons of Kareah), Seraiah (son of Tanhumeth), the sons of Ephai from Netophah, and Jezaniah, who was the son of a man from Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, swore an oath to them and their men. He said, “Don’t be afraid to serve the Babylonians. Live in this country, serve the king of Babylon, and you will prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to live in Mizpah and represent you when the Babylonians come to us. Gather grapes, summer fruit, and olive oil, and put them in storage jars. Live in the cities you have taken over.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, all the Jews who were in Moab, Ammon, Edom, and in all the other countries heard that the king of Babylon had left a few survivors in Judah and had appointed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, to govern them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the Jews returned from all the places where they had been scattered. They came to Judah and to Gedaliah at Mizpah. They gathered a large harvest of grapes and summer fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were still in the country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked him, “Do you know that King Baalis of the Ammonites has sent Ishmael, Nethaniah’s son, to kill you?” However, Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, didn’t believe them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Johanan, Kareah’s son, secretly asked Gedaliah at Mizpah, “Let me kill Ishmael, Nethaniah’s son. No one will know about it. Why should he kill you? All the Jews who have gathered around you would scatter. What is left of Judah would disappear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, told Johanan, Kareah’s son, “Don’t do that! What you are saying about Ishmael is a lie.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh month Ishmael (son of Nethaniah and grandson of Elishama, a descendant of the royal family and of the king’s officers) went with ten men to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, at Mizpah. As they ate together at Mizpah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and the ten men who were with him got up, drew their swords, and killed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan. So they assassinated the man whom the king of Babylon had appointed to govern the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael also killed all the Jews who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah as well as the Babylonian soldiers that he found there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The day after the murder of Gedaliah, before anyone knew about it,
speaker: Narrator

text: 80 men arrived from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria. Their beards were shaved off, their clothes were torn, and cuts were on their bodies. They brought grain offerings and incense to the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, left Mizpah to meet them, crying as he went. When he met them, he said to them, “Come to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came into the city, Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and his men slaughtered them and threw them into a cistern.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, ten men from the group had said to Ishmael, “Don’t kill us! We have wheat, barley, olive oil, and honey hidden in the country.” So he left them alone and didn’t kill them along with the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, the cistern where Ishmael threw all the bodies of the men he had killed was the same one that King Asa made as a part of his defense against King Baasha of Israel. Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, filled it with the bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ishmael took captive the rest of the people who were at Mizpah. He captured the king’s daughters and all the other people who had been left at Mizpah. They were the people whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had put under the control of Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, took them captive and left for Ammon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were with him heard about all the crimes Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: they took all their men and went to fight Ishmael. They caught up with him at the large pool in Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people who were with Ishmael saw Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were with him, they were glad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people Ishmael had taken captive at Mizpah turned and ran to Kareah’s son Johanan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael and eight of his men escaped from Johanan and fled to Ammon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Kareah’s son Johanan and all the army commanders who were with him brought back the rest of the people of Mizpah whom he had rescued from Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, after Ishmael had killed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. Johanan brought back men, women, children, soldiers, and commanders from Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they left Gibeon, they stayed near Bethlehem at Geruth Kimham on their way to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were afraid of the Babylonians because Ishmael had killed Gedaliah whom the king of Babylon had appointed to govern the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the army commanders along with Kareah’s son Johanan and Hoshaiah’s son Jezaniah and all the people, from the least important to the most important, came to the prophet Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Please listen to our request, and pray to the Lord your God for all of us who are left here. As you can see, there are only a few of us left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the Lord your God tell us where we should go and what we should do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Jeremiah answered them, “I have listened to your request. I will pray to the Lord your God as you have requested, and I will tell you everything the Lord says. I won’t keep anything from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Jeremiah, “May the Lord be a true and faithful witness against us if we don’t do exactly what the Lord your God tells us to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will obey the Lord our God to whom we are sending you, whether it’s good or bad. Yes, we will obey the Lord our God so that everything will go well for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After ten days the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jeremiah called Kareah’s son Johanan, all the army commanders who were with him, and all the people from the least important to the most important.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah said to them, “You sent me to plead your case humbly to the Lord. This is what the Lord God of Israel says:
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose you stay in this land. Then I will build you up and not tear you down. I will plant you and not uproot you. I will change my plans about the disaster I’ve brought on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be afraid of the king of Babylon, whom you now fear. Don’t be afraid of him, declares the Lord. I’m with you. I will save you and rescue you from his power.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will have compassion on you. I will make him have compassion on you and return you to your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose you say, ‘We won’t stay in this land,’ and you disobey the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you say, ‘We’ll go to Egypt, where we won’t have to see war, hear the sound of a ram’s horn, or be hungry. We’ll stay there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, listen to the Lord’s word, you people who are left in Judah. This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Suppose you’re determined to go to Egypt, and you go and live there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the wars you fear will catch up with you in Egypt. The famines you dread will follow you to Egypt, and you will die there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people who decide to go and live in Egypt will die in wars, famines, and plagues. No one will survive or escape the disasters I will bring on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: As my anger and my fury were poured out on those who live in Jerusalem, so my fury will be poured out on you if you go to Egypt. You will become a curse word. You will become something ridiculed, cursed, and disgraced. You won’t see this place again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord has told you people who are left in Judah not to go to Egypt. You need to know that I am warning you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: You only deceived yourselves when you sent me to the Lord your God and said, ‘Pray to the Lord our God for us, and tell us everything that the Lord our God says, and we’ll do it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I have told you today, but you won’t obey anything the Lord your God sent me to tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, you need to know that you will die in wars, famines, or plagues in the place where you want to go and live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jeremiah finished telling all the people the message from the Lord their God. He told them everything the Lord their God sent him to tell them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah (son of Hoshaiah), Johanan (son of Kareah), and all the arrogant people said to Jeremiah, “You’re lying! The Lord our God didn’t send you to tell us that we must not go to live in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Baruch, son of Neriah, has turned you against us in order to hand us over to the Babylonians. Then they will kill us or take us as captives to Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Johanan (son of Kareah), all the army commanders, and all the people didn’t obey the Lord. They didn’t stay in Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Johanan (son of Kareah) and all the army commanders took all the people who were left in Judah to Egypt. These were all the people who had come back to Judah from the places where they had been scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took men, women, children, and the king’s daughters. They took every person whom Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, had left with Gedaliah, son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan, including the prophet Jeremiah and Baruch, son of Neriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They didn’t listen to the Lord, so they went to Egypt. They went as far as Tahpanhes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah in Tahpanhes. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take some large stones, and bury them under the brick pavement at the entrance to the Pharaoh’s palace in Tahpanhes. Do this while the people of Judah watch you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I’m going to send for my servant King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. I will set his throne over these stones that I buried, and I will spread his royal canopy above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will defeat Egypt. He will bring death to those who are supposed to die. He will capture those who are supposed to be captured. He will kill in battle those who are supposed to be killed in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He  will set fire to the temples of Egypt’s gods. He will burn down the temples and take their gods captive. Nebuchadnezzar will put on Egypt as his coat as a shepherd puts on his coat. He will leave Egypt peacefully.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Beth Shemesh he will break the monuments in Egypt and burn down the temples of Egypt’s gods.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to Jeremiah about all the Jews living in Egypt at Migdol, Tahpanhes, Noph, and Pathros.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: You have seen all the disasters I brought on Jerusalem and on all the cities of Judah. Today they are deserted ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is because their people did evil, and they made me angry. They went to burn incense and serve other gods that neither you nor your ancestors heard of.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have sent my servants the prophets to you again and again to tell you not to do these detestable things that I hate.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you wouldn’t listen or pay attention. You wouldn’t turn from your wicked ways and wouldn’t stop burning incense as an offering to other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why my fury and anger were poured out and continued to burn in the cities of Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem. So they became the desolate ruin that they are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, this is what the Lord God of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Why do you bring this terrible disaster on yourselves? Why do you keep destroying men, women, children, and babies from Judah until none are left?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you make me angry by burning incense to other gods in Egypt, where you have come to live. You will destroy yourselves and be cursed and ridiculed by all the nations on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you forgotten the wicked things done by your ancestors, by the kings of Judah and their wives, and by you and your wives in Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem?
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not humbled yourselves even to this day. You haven’t feared me or lived your lives by my teachings or by my decrees that I gave your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: I’m going to bring disaster on you and destroy all of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take away from Judah those who are left, those who were determined to go to live in Egypt. They will die in Egypt. All of them, from the least important to the most important, will die in wars or be brought to an end by famines. They will become something cursed, ridiculed, and disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish those living in Egypt as I punished Jerusalem with wars, famines, and plagues.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of the people of Judah who went to live in Egypt will survive or return to Judah, where they long to return and live. Only a few refugees will return there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men who knew that their wives were burning incense to other gods, all the women who were standing there, and all the people who lived at Pathros in Egypt answered Jeremiah. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “We won’t listen to the message that you have spoken to us in the Lord’s name.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will do everything we said we would do. We will burn incense to the queen of heaven and pour out wine offerings to her as our ancestors, our kings, and our officials did in the cities of Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem. We had plenty to eat then, and we lived comfortably and saw no disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: But since we stopped burning incense to the queen of heaven and pouring out wine offerings to her, we have had nothing but wars and famines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The women added, “When we burned incense to the queen of heaven, poured out wine offerings to her, and made cakes for her with her image on them, do you think our husbands didn’t approve?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, both men and women, to everyone who answered him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Doesn’t the Lord remember that you burned incense in the cities of Judah and on the streets of Jerusalem along with your ancestors, your kings and your officials, and the people in the land?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord could no longer bear the wicked and detestable things you did. That is why your land has become something ruined, destroyed, and cursed. No one lives in that land today.
speaker: Narrator

text: You burned incense as offerings to other gods, sinned against the Lord, and wouldn’t obey him. You didn’t live by his teachings, decrees, or written instructions. That is why you have met with this disaster as it is today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeremiah said to all the people, including the women, “Listen to the Lord’s word, all you people of Judah who are in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: You and your wives made promises, and you have kept them. You said, ‘We will certainly do what we vow. We will burn incense to the queen of heaven and pour out wine offerings to her.’
“So go ahead. Keep your vows, and do what you vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: But listen to the Lord’s word, all you people of Judah who live in Egypt. ‘I swear by my great name,’ says the Lord, ‘that no one from Judah who lives anywhere in Egypt will ever again call on my name and take the oath, “As the Almighty Lord lives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to watch over them. I am going to watch over them to bring disasters, not blessings. In Egypt the people from Judah will die in wars and famines until everyone is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who escape the wars will return to Judah from Egypt. Then all the people of Judah who went to live in Egypt will know whose words have come true, mine or theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you this sign,’ declares the Lord. ‘I will punish you in this place so that you will know that my threats of disaster will happen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: I’m going to hand Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, over to his enemies and to those who want to kill him, just as I handed over King Zedekiah of Judah to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and to those who wanted to kill him.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the message that the prophet Jeremiah spoke to Baruch, son of Neriah. Baruch wrote these things on a scroll as Jeremiah dictated them during the fourth year that Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, was king of Judah. Jeremiah said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says to you, Baruch:
speaker: Narrator

text: You said, ‘I’m so miserable! The Lord has added grief to my pain. I’m worn out from groaning. I can’t find any rest.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say this to Baruch, ‘This is what the Lord says: I will tear down what I have built. I will uproot what I have planted throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you looking for great things for yourself? Don’t look for them, because I’m going to bring disaster on all people, declares the Lord. But wherever you go I will let you escape with your life.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke this message to the prophet Jeremiah about the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the message about Egypt, about the army of Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt. King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon defeated his army at Carchemish along the Euphrates River during the fourth year that Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, was king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get your large and small shields ready; advance into battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Harness your horses. Mount up, you horsemen.
Take your positions, and put on your helmets.
Polish your spears.
Put on your armor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do I see in them?
They are terrified.
They are retreating.
Their warriors are defeated.
They flee without looking back.
Terror is all around them,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The infantry can’t flee.
The warriors can’t escape.
They stumble and fall in the north by the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this, rising like the Nile River,
like streams that flow swiftly?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Egypt is like the rising Nile River,
like a river quickly overflowing its banks.
Egypt says, ‘I will rise; I will cover the earth.
I will destroy cities and the people in them.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go into battle, you horsemen.
Drive wildly, you chariot drivers.
March into battle, you warriors,
you warriors from Sudan and Put who carry shields,
you warriors from Lydia who use bows and arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That day belongs to the Almighty Lord of Armies.
It is a day of vengeance when he will take revenge on his enemies.
His sword will devour until it has had enough,
and it will drink their blood until it’s full.
The Almighty Lord of Armies will offer them as sacrifices
in the north by the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go to Gilead, and get medicine, dear people of Egypt.
You have used many medicines without results; you can’t be cured.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations have heard of your shame; your cry fills the earth.
One warrior will stumble over another,
and both will fall together.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke this message to the prophet Jeremiah about the coming of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, who will defeat Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Tell this in Egypt; announce this in Migdol.
Make it known in Memphis and in Tahpanhes.
Say, ‘Take your positions, and get ready.
Swords will kill those around you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should your soldiers be cut down?
They can’t stand because the Lord will push them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have repeatedly stumbled, and now they have fallen.
They say to each other,
‘Get up! Let’s go back to our people,
to the land where we were born,
and escape our enemy’s sword.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they will cry, ‘Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is a big windbag.
He has missed his chance.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As I live,” declares the king, whose name is the Lord of Armies,
“someone who is like Mount Tabor among the mountains will come.
Someone who is like Mount Carmel by the sea will come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pack your bags, inhabitants of Egypt,
because you will be taken away as captives.
Memphis will become a dreary wasteland,
a pile of rubble where no one lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Egypt is like a beautiful cow,
but a horsefly from the north will attack it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Egypt’s hired soldiers are like fattened calves.
They will turn and run away together.
They won’t stand their ground.
The day of destruction is coming.
At that time they will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Egypt will hiss like a snake as it slithers away.
Its enemies will come with full force.
They will attack it with axes like those who chop wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will cut down the forest,” declares the Lord,
“since Egypt can’t be found.
They are more numerous than locusts; they can’t be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Egypt will be put to shame.
They will be handed over to the people from the north.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says,
“I’m going to punish Amon, who is the god of Thebes.
I will also punish Pharaoh, Egypt, its gods, its kings,
and whoever trusts Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll hand them over to those who want to kill them,
to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and his officers.
Afterward, they will live in peace as they did long ago,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Don’t be afraid, my servant Jacob.
Don’t be terrified, Israel.
I’m going to rescue you and your descendants from a faraway land,
from the land where you are captives.
Then Jacob’s descendants will again have undisturbed peace,
and no one will make them afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be afraid, my servant Jacob,” declares the Lord.
“I am with you.
I will completely destroy all the nations where I scattered you,
but I will not completely destroy you.
I will correct you with justice.
I won’t let you go entirely unpunished.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke this message to the prophet Jeremiah about the Philistines before Pharaoh defeated Gaza.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
Water is rising in the north.
It will become an overflowing river.
It will overflow the land and everything in it,
the cities and those who live in them.
People will cry out and everyone who lives in the land will cry loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will hear the sound of galloping war horses,
the rattling of enemy chariots,
and the rumbling of their wheels.
Fathers who lack courage abandon their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The time has come to destroy all the Philistines,
to cut off from Tyre and Sidon any Philistine
who might have escaped to get help.
The Lord will destroy the Philistines
and anyone who is left from the island of Crete.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gaza will shave its head in mourning.
Ashkelon will be destroyed.
How long will you cut yourselves, you people left on the plains?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You cry out, “Sword of the Lord,
how long will you keep on fighting?
Go back into your scabbard.
Stay there and rest!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can the sword of the Lord rest?
The Lord has ordered it to attack Ashkelon and the coast.
He has put it there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says about Moab:
How horrible it will be for Nebo; it will be destroyed.
Kiriathaim will be put to shame; it will be captured.
Its stronghold will be put to shame and torn down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will no longer praise Moab.
The people in Heshbon will plan Moab’s destruction.
“Let’s destroy that nation!”
You will be silenced, city of Madmen.
Death will come after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will cry out from Horonaim, “Looting and great destruction!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab will be broken.
Its little ones will cry out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People go up the pass of Luhith, crying bitterly as they go.
On the road down to Horonaim they have heard
the distressful cry of destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Run away! Run for your lives!
Run like a wild donkey in the desert.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Since you trust the things you do and your treasures,
you will be captured.
Chemosh will go into captivity with all its priests and officials.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The destroyer will come to every city, and no city will escape.
The valley will be destroyed, and the plain will be laid waste
as the Lord has threatened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Put salt on Moab.
It will be destroyed.
Its cities will become deserted ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed are those who neglect doing the Lord’s work.
Cursed are those who keep their swords from killing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Moab has lived securely ever since it was young.
Its people are like wine left to settle in a jar.
They aren’t poured from one jar to another.
They haven’t gone into captivity.
That is why its flavor has remained the same,
and its aroma hasn’t changed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why the days are coming,” declares the Lord,
“when I will send people to pour Moab out of its jars
and to smash its pitchers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Moab will be ashamed of Chemosh
as the nation of Israel was ashamed when it trusted Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How can you say, ‘We are soldiers and warriors’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The enemy will attack Moab and destroy its cities.
Its finest young men will be slaughtered,”
declares the king, whose name is the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Moab’s destruction is coming near; disaster is coming quickly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mourn over it, all of its neighbors and everyone who knows its fame.
Say, ‘Look at the strong staff, the beautiful rod, that is broken!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“People of Dibon, come down from your place of honor
and sit on the dry ground.
The destroyers of Moab will attack you.
They will destroy your fortresses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stand by the road in Aroer, and watch.
Ask those who are fleeing
and those who are escaping what is happening.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will answer, ‘Moab is disgraced; it is defeated.
Shout loudly, and cry.
Tell the news in Arnon that Moab is destroyed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Judgment has come to all the cities on the plain: to Holon, Jahzah, Mephaath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dibon, Nebo, Beth Diblathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kiriathaim, Beth Gamul, Beth Meon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kerioth, Bozrah, and on all the cities of Moab, far and near.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Moab’s horn is cut off, and its arm is broken,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Get the people of Moab drunk; they have spoken against the Lord.
They will wallow in their own vomit, and people will laugh at them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People of Moab, didn’t you laugh at the people of Israel?
Were they caught among thieves?
Whenever you talk about them you shake your heads in contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People of Moab, abandon your cities.
Live among the cliffs.
Be like doves that make their nests at the entrance of a cave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have heard about the arrogance of Moab’s people.
They are very arrogant.
They are very arrogant, conceited, and boastful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know how arrogant they are,” declares the Lord,
“but it isn’t right.
They brag and don’t do what they say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why I will weep for Moab and cry for all of Moab.
I will moan for the people of Kir Hareseth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will cry for you as Jazer cries.
I will cry for you, grapevines of Sibmah.
Your branches once spread as far as the sea,
and they reached as far as the sea of Jazer.
The destroyer will destroy your ripened fruits and your grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joy and gladness have disappeared from the orchards and fields of Moab.
I will stop the wine flowing from the winepresses.
No one will stomp on grapes with shouts of joy.
There will be shouts, but not shouts of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The cry will be heard from Heshbon to Elealeh and Jahaz. It will be heard from Zoar to Horonaim and Eglath Shelishiyah. Even the streams of Nimrim will dry up.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will stop those in Moab who come to worship sites, those who bring offerings to their gods,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why I moan for Moab like a flute. I sound like a flute for the people of Kir Hareseth. The wealth they gained has disappeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every head is shaved, and every beard is cut off. There are gashes on every hand and sackcloth on every waist.
speaker: Narrator

text: People in Moab will mourn on every rooftop and in every street. There will be mourning everywhere, because I will break Moab like a jar that no one wants,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They will cry, ‘Look how Moab is defeated! Moab turns away in shame!’ Moab has become something ridiculed and something held in contempt by everyone around it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord says:
The enemy will swoop down like eagles and spread their wings over Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The cities will be taken, and the fortified places will be captured.
On that day Moab’s soldiers will be like women in childbirth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab will be destroyed as a nation,
because it spoke against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Disasters, pits, and traps are in store for those who live in Moab,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Whoever flees from a disaster will fall into a pit.
Whoever climbs out of the pit will be caught in a trap.
I will bring a year of punishment to Moab,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Those who flee will stand exhausted in the shadow of Heshbon.
A fire will come out of Heshbon and a flame from Sihon.
It will burn the foreheads of the people of Moab
and the skulls of those noisy people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How horrible it will be for you, Moab.
You people of Chemosh will die.
Your sons will be taken away into exile,
and your daughters will be taken away into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will restore Moab in the last days,” declares the Lord.
The judgment against Moab ends here.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says about the people of Ammon:
Doesn’t Israel have any children? Doesn’t it have any heirs?
Why, then, has the god Milcom  taken over the inheritance
of Gad’s descendants?
Why do Milcom’s people live in Gad’s cities?
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why the days are coming, declares the Lord,
when I will sound the battle cry against Rabbah,
where the people of Ammon live.
It will become a pile of rubble.
Its villages will be burned down.
Then Israel will take possession of its inheritance, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cry loudly, Heshbon, because Ai is destroyed.
Cry, people of Rabbah, put on your sackcloth, and mourn.
Run back and forth between the walls.
Milcom will be taken away into captivity
with its priests and officials.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you brag about your valleys,
your fertile valleys, you unfaithful people?
You trust your treasures.
You think, “Who would attack me?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am going to bring terror on you from all around,
declares the Almighty Lord of Armies.
Everyone will be scattered.
No one will gather the refugees.
speaker: Narrator

text: But afterward, I will return the captives of Ammon, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says about Edom:
Is there no longer any wisdom in Teman?
Has wisdom disappeared from your people?
Has their wisdom vanished?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn and run.
Hide in deep caves, inhabitants of Dedan.
When I punish them,
I will bring disaster on the descendants of Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If people come to pick your grapes,
won’t they leave a few grapes behind?
If thieves come during the night,
won’t they steal only until they’ve had enough?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, I will strip the descendants of Esau.
I will find their hiding places.
They won’t be able to hide.
Their children and relatives will be destroyed.
None of their neighbors will say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Abandon your orphans, and I will keep them alive.
Your widows can trust me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: If those who don’t deserve to drink from the cup still drink from it, why should you go unpunished? You won’t go unpunished. You must drink from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I take an oath on myself, declares the Lord, that Bozrah will become a pile of rubble. It will become something horrifying, ridiculed, ruined, and cursed. All its cities will lie in ruins permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I heard a message from the Lord.
A messenger was sent among the nations to say,
“Assemble, and attack Edom.
Get ready for battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Edom, I will make you the smallest of nations
and despised among humanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have frightened other people.
Your arrogance has deceived you.
You live on rocky cliffs
and occupy the highest places in the hills.
Even though you build your nest as high as an eagle,
I will bring you down from there,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then Edom will become something horrible.
Everyone who passes by it will be horrified
and hiss at all its wounds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Edom will be like Sodom, Gomorrah, and their neighboring cities
when they were destroyed.
No one will live there.
No human will stay there,” says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will suddenly chase them from their places
like a lion coming out of the jungle
along the Jordan River into pastureland.
I will appoint over Edom whomever I choose.
Who is like me? Who can challenge me?
Is there any leader who can stand up to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to the plans that the Lord is making against Edom
and the things he intends to do to those who live in Teman.
He will surely drag away the little ones of the flock.
He will surely destroy the pasture
because of the people who live in Teman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth will quake at the sound of their downfall.
The sound of their crying will be heard at the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The enemy will swoop down like eagles
and spread their wings over Bozrah.
On that day Edom’s soldiers will be like women in childbirth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is a message about Damascus.
“Hamath and Arpad are worried because they heard the bad news.
They melt in fear.
They are troubled like a sea that can’t be calmed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Damascus are weak.
They turn to flee, but panic grips them.
Anguish and pain grip them like a woman in labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why isn’t that famous, happy city abandoned?
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why its young men will die in the streets,
and its soldiers will be silenced that day,”
declares the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will set fire to the walls of Damascus
and burn down Benhadad’s palaces.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is about the tribe of Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor that King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon defeated. This is what the Lord says:
Get ready, attack Kedar,
and loot the people from the east.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their tents and their flocks will be taken.
Their tent curtains, utensils, and camels will be carried away.
People will shout to them, “Terror is all around!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Run far away! Find a place to hide,
inhabitants of Hazor, declares the Lord.
King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon has made plans against you
and intends to attack you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get ready! Attack the nation living peacefully and securely,
declares the Lord.
It is a nation with no gates or bars.
Its people live alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their camels will be taken as prizes.
Their large herds will be taken as loot.
I will scatter to the winds
those who shave the hair on their foreheads.
I will bring disaster on them from every side,
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazor will be a place where only jackals live.
It will become a permanent wasteland.
No one will live there.
No human will stay there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the rule of King Zedekiah of Judah, the Lord spoke his word to the prophet Jeremiah about Elam.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
I’m going to break the bows of Elam’s archers,
the most important weapon of their strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll bring the four winds
from the four corners of heaven against Elam
and scatter its people in every direction.
There won’t be a nation
where Elam’s refugees won’t go.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll defeat the people of Elam in the presence of their enemies,
in the presence of those who want to kill them.
I’ll bring disaster with my burning anger, declares the Lord.
I’ll send armies after them until I put an end to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll set my throne in Elam and destroy its king and officials,
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But afterward, I’ll return the captives of Elam, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the message that the Lord spoke about Babylon and the land of the Babylonians through the prophet Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Announce this among the nations, and spread the news.
Raise a flag, and announce it.
Don’t hide anything.
Say, ‘Babylon will be captured.
Bel will be put to shame.
Marduk will be filled with terror.
Babylon’s statues will be put to shame.
Its idols will be filled with terror.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
A nation from the north will attack Babylon
and destroy its land so that no one will live in it.
People and animals will run away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In those days and at that time,” declares the Lord,
“the people of Israel and Judah will cry as they go together
to seek the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will ask which road goes to Zion and turn in that direction.
They will go there to make a permanent agreement with the Lord.
It will not be forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people have been lost sheep.
Their shepherds have led them astray.
They wander around on the mountains.
They go from mountains to hills.
They have forgotten their resting place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone who finds them eats them.
Their enemies say, ‘We’re not guilty.
They have sinned against the Lord, their true pasture.
They have sinned against the Lord, the hope of their ancestors.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Run away from Babylon.
Leave the land of the Babylonians.
Be like the male goats that lead the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am going to stir up an alliance of strong nations from the north
and bring it against Babylon.
Those nations will take up positions against Babylon.
Babylon will be captured from the north.
Its enemy’s arrows will be like skilled soldiers
who don’t come back empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Babylonians will become the prize.
All who loot them will get everything they want,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are happy and excited.
You have looted the people who belong to me.
You dance around like calves on the grass
and neigh like stallions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But your mother will be greatly ashamed.
The woman who gave birth to you will be disgraced.
Babylon, you will be the least important nation.
You will become a parched desert.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one will live in Babylon because of the Lord’s anger.
It will be completely abandoned.
Everyone who passes by Babylon will be horrified
and hiss at all its wounds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Take up your positions around Babylon, all you archers with bows.
Shoot at it; don’t save any arrows,
because the people of Babylon have sinned against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shout a war cry against them on every side.
They’ll surrender.
Their towers will fall and their walls will be torn down.
Since this is the Lord’s vengeance, take revenge against them.
Do to them what they did to others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t allow anyone in Babylon to plant or harvest.
Everyone will turn to his own people and flee to his own homeland
because of the enemies’ swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The people of Israel are like scattered sheep that lions have chased.
The first to devour them was the king of Assyria.
The last to gnaw at their bones was King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says:
I am going to punish the king of Babylon and his land
as I punished the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring the people of Israel back to their pastures.
They will eat on Mount Carmel and Mount Bashan.
They will eat until they are full
on the mountains of Ephraim and Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In those days and at that time,” declares the Lord,
“people will look for Israel’s crimes, but they will find none.
They will look for Judah’s sins, but none will be found.
I will forgive the faithful few whom I have spared.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Attack the land of Merathaim
and the people who live in Pekod.
Claim them for me by killing them with a sword,”
declares the Lord.
“Do everything I commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The noise of battle and great destruction fills the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hammer of the whole earth is broken and shattered.
See how desolate Babylon is of all the nations!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will set traps for you, Babylon.
You will be caught, but you won’t know it.
You will be found and captured
because you have opposed the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will open his armory
and bring out the weapons of his fury,
because the Almighty Lord of Armies
has a job to do in the land of the Babylonians.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Attack them from a distance,
open their storehouses,
pile up their corpses like piles of grain,
claim them for me by destroying them,
and don’t leave anyone behind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kill all their young bulls.
Let them go to be slaughtered.
How horrible it will be for them when their time has come,
the time for them to be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen! Fugitives and refugees from Babylon
are coming to Zion to tell about
the vengeance of the Lord our God, the vengeance for his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Call together the archers, the soldiers with bows, against Babylon.
Set up blockades around it. Don’t let anyone escape.
Pay the people of Babylon back for what they have done.
Do to them what they did to others.
They have disobeyed the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why their young men will die in the streets,
and all their soldiers will be silenced that day,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’m against you, you arrogant city,”
declares the Almighty Lord of Armies.
“Your day has come, the time when I will punish you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those arrogant people will stumble and fall,
and there will be no one to help them get up.
I will light a fire in their cities
that will burn up everything around them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
All the people of Israel and Judah are oppressed.
All their enemies have captured them.
They refuse to let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their defender is strong.
His name is the Lord of Armies.
He will certainly take up their cause
in order to bring rest to the land of Israel
and unrest to the people who live in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A sword will kill the Babylonians and everyone who lives in Babylon,”
declares the Lord.
“A sword will kill their officials and their wise men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A sword will kill the false prophets.
They will become fools.
A sword will kill their soldiers and defeat them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A sword will kill their horses, their chariots,
and all the foreigners within their ranks.
They will become women.
A sword will destroy their treasures, and they will be looted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A drought will diminish their water supply, and it will dry up.
Babylon is a land of idols, statues that will go crazy with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why desert animals will live with hyenas.
Desert owls will also live there.
It will no longer be inhabited or lived in for generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon will be like Sodom, Gomorrah, and their neighboring cities
when I, God, destroyed them.
No one will live there.
No human will stay there,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“People are going to come from the north.
A great nation and many kings will rise from the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will take hold of bows and spears.
They will be cruel and have no compassion.
They will sound like the sea when it roars.
They will ride horses.
They are ready for war, ready to attack you, people of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king of Babylon has heard reports about them, and he loses courage.
Anguish will grip him as pain grips a woman in labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will suddenly chase them from their places
like a lion coming out of the jungle
along the Jordan River into pastureland.
I will appoint over Babylon whomever I choose.
Who is like me? Who can challenge me?
Is there any leader who can stand up to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to the plans that the Lord is making against Babylon
and the things he intends to do to the land of the Babylonians.
He will surely drag away the little ones of the flock.
He will surely destroy the pasture because of the Babylonians.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth will quake at the news that Babylon has been captured.
Its cry will be heard among the nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
I will stir up a destructive wind against Babylon
and against the people who live in Leb Kamai.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will send people to winnow  Babylon,
to winnow it and strip its land bare.
They will attack it from every direction on the day of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the archers bend their bows.
Have them put on their armor.
Don’t spare Babylon’s young men.
Completely destroy its whole army.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon’s soldiers will fall down badly wounded in their streets.
They will lie dead in their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel and Judah haven’t been abandoned by their God, the Lord of Armies, although their land is guilty of abandoning the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Run away from Babylon!
Run for your lives!
You shouldn’t die because of Babylon’s crimes.
This is the time for the vengeance of the Lord.
He will pay the people of Babylon back for what they have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon was a golden cup in the Lord’s hand.
It made the whole world drunk.
The nations drank its wine.
That is why the nations have gone insane.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon will suddenly fall and be shattered.
Cry for it.
Bring medicine for its pain.
Maybe it can be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We wanted to heal Babylon, but it couldn’t be healed.
Let’s abandon it and go to our own land.
God has judged Babylon.
Its judgment is complete.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has brought about our victory.
Let’s announce in Zion what the Lord our God has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sharpen the arrows; fill the quivers.
The Lord will stir up the spirit of the kings of the Medes
because his plan is to destroy Babylon.
The Lord will avenge his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Raise your battle flag in front of the walls of Babylon.
Strengthen the guards.
Station watchmen.
Prepare ambushes.
The Lord will carry out his plans
against the people who live in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon, you live beside many rivers and are rich with treasures,
but your end has come.
The thread of your life has been cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Armies has taken an oath on himself:
“I will certainly fill you with many enemy armies.
They will swarm like locusts.
People will shout their victory over you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord made the earth by his power.
He set up the world by his wisdom.
He stretched out heaven by his understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he thunders, the water in the sky roars.
He makes clouds rise from the ends of the earth.
He sends lightning with the rain.
He brings wind out of his storehouses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone is stupid and ignorant.
Metalsmiths are put to shame by their idols.
Their statues are false gods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They can’t breathe.
They are worthless jokes.
When they are punished, they will disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob’s God isn’t like them.
He made everything,
and Israel is the tribe that belongs to him.
His name is the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are my war club and my weapon for battle.
I will use you to crush nations.
I will use you to destroy kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will use you to crush horses and their riders.
I will use you to crush chariots and their drivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will use you to crush men and women.
I will use you to crush the old and the young.
I will use you to crush young men and women.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will use you to crush shepherds and their flocks.
I will use you to crush farmers and their oxen.
I will use you to crush governors and officials.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In your presence I will pay back Babylon
and all the people who live in Babylon
for all the evil things that they did in Zion,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am against you, Babylon, you destructive mountain.
You have destroyed the whole earth,” declares the Lord.
“I will use my power against you,
roll you off the cliffs,
and make you a scorched mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People won’t find any stones in you to use as a cornerstone.
They won’t find any stones in you to use for a foundation.
You will become permanent ruins,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Raise your battle flag throughout the world.
Blow the ram’s horn among the nations.
Prepare nations to attack Babylon.
Tell the kingdoms of Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz to attack it.
Appoint a commander to lead the attack.
Bring up horses like a swarm of locusts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prepare nations to attack Babylon.
Prepare the king of the Medes, their governors, all their deputies,
and all the countries that they rule.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth trembles and writhes in pain.
The Lord carries out his plans against Babylon
to make Babylon a wasteland so that no one will live there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The warriors of Babylon have stopped fighting.
They stay in their fortified cities.
Their strength has failed. They have become women.
Their buildings are set on fire.
The bars across their gates are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Runners run to meet runners.
Messengers follow messengers.
They inform the king of Babylon that his entire city is captured.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The river crossings have been taken.
The enemy has burned its marshes,
and its soldiers are terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says:
The people of Babylon are like a threshing floor 
at the time it is trampled.
Their harvest time will come soon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon has devoured us.
He has thrown us into confusion.
He has turned us into empty jars.
He has swallowed us like a monster.
He has filled his belly with our delicacies.
Then he spit us out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people who live in Zion say,
“May the violence done to us be done to Babylon.”
Jerusalem says,
“May the people of Babylon be held responsible for our deaths.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
I am going to take up your cause and get revenge for you.
I will dry up Babylon’s sea and make its springs dry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon will become piles of rubble.
It will become a dwelling place for jackals,
something horrible, and an object of contempt,
where no one lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its people are like roaring lions and growling lion cubs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they are excited,
I will prepare a feast for them
and make them drunk so that they will shout and laugh.
They will fall into a deep sleep and never wake up again,
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take them to be slaughtered like lambs, rams, and male goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sheshach has been captured.
Babylon, the city that the whole world praised, has been taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What a horrifying sight Babylon will be to the nations!
The sea will rise over Babylon,
and its roaring waves will cover it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its cities will be ruined.
It will become a desert, a land where no one lives
and where no human travels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will punish Bel in Babylon.
I will make Bel spit out everything that it has swallowed.
Nations will no longer stream to Babylon,
and its walls will fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Leave it, my people!
Run for your lives!
Run from the burning anger of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t lose courage or be afraid when rumors are heard in the land.
One rumor comes one year; another rumor comes the next year.
Rumors of violence are in the land.
Rumors that one ruler will fight against another are in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why the days are coming when I will punish Babylon’s idols.
The whole country will be put to shame,
and all its soldiers will lie dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then heaven and earth and everything in them will rejoice over Babylon,
because destroyers from the north will attack it,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because the people of Babylon have killed many Israelites
and because they have killed many people throughout the earth,
Babylon must fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You people who escaped from the sword, leave!
Don’t just stand there.
Remember the Lord in a distant land, and think about Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have been put to shame, and we have been disgraced.
Shame covers our faces, because foreigners have gone
into the holy places of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That is why the days are coming,” declares the Lord,
“when I will punish their idols,
and those who are wounded will moan everywhere in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Babylon might go up to heaven.
They might fortify their strongholds.
But destroyers will still come from me against them,”
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cries of agony are heard from Babylon.
Sounds of terrible destruction are heard
from the land of the Babylonians.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will destroy Babylon.
He will silence the loud noise coming from it.
Waves of enemies will come roaring in like raging water.
The noise will be heard everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A destroyer will attack Babylon,
its soldiers will be captured,
and their bows and arrows will be broken. 
“I, the Lord, am a God who punishes evil.
I will certainly punish them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make their officials and wise men drunk,
along with their governors, officers, and soldiers.
They will fall into a deep sleep and never wake up,”
declares the king, whose name is the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
The thick walls of Babylon will be leveled,
and its high gates will be set on fire.
People exhaust themselves for nothing.
The nations wear themselves out only to have a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the message that the prophet Jeremiah gave to Seraiah, son of Neriah and grandson of Mahseiah, when Seraiah went to Babylon with King Zedekiah of Judah in the fourth year of Zedekiah’s rule. (Seraiah was the quartermaster.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah wrote on a scroll all the disasters that would happen to Babylon. He wrote all these things that have been written about Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah said to Seraiah, “When you come to Babylon, see that you read all this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say, ‘Lord, you have threatened to destroy this place so that no person or animal will live here, and it will become a permanent ruin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When you finish reading this scroll, tie a stone to it and throw it into the middle of the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say, ‘Babylon will sink like this scroll. It will never rise again because of the disasters that I will bring on it.’ ”
The words of Jeremiah end here.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah was 21 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah from Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah did what the Lord considered evil, as Jehoiakim had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord became angry with Jerusalem and Judah and threw the people out of his sight.
Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of the tenth month of the ninth year of Zedekiah’s reign, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked Jerusalem with his entire army. They set up camp and built dirt ramps around the city walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: The blockade of the city lasted until Zedekiah’s eleventh year as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ninth day of the fourth month, the famine in the city became so severe that the common people had no food.
speaker: Narrator

text: The enemy broke through the city walls, and all Judah’s soldiers fled. They left the city at night through the gate between the two walls beside the king’s garden. While the Babylonians were attacking the city from all sides, they took the road to the plain of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonian army pursued King Zedekiah and caught up with him in the plain of Jericho. His entire army had deserted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonians captured the king and brought him to the king of Babylon at Riblah in Hamath, where the king of Babylon passed sentence on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah’s sons as Zedekiah watched. He also slaughtered all the officials of Judah at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he blinded Zedekiah and put him in bronze shackles. The king of Babylon took him to Babylon and put him in a prison, where he stayed until he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of the fifth month of Nebuchadnezzar’s nineteenth year as king of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, who was the captain of the guard and an officer of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned down the Lord’s temple, the royal palace, and all the houses in Jerusalem. Every important building was burned down.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire Babylonian army that was with the captain of the guard tore down the walls around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, captured the few people left in the city, those who surrendered to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the population.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, left some of the poorest people in the land to work in the vineyards and on the farms.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonians broke apart the bronze pillars of the Lord’s temple, the stands, and the bronze pool in the Lord’s temple. They shipped all the bronze to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the pots, shovels, snuffers, bowls, dishes, and all the bronze utensils used in the temple service.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard also took pans, incense burners, bowls, pots, lamp stands, dishes, and the bowls used for wine offerings. The captain of the guard took all of the trays and bowls that were made of gold or silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bronze from the 2 pillars, the pool, and the 12 bronze bulls under the stands that King Solomon had made for the Lord’s temple couldn’t be weighed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One pillar was 27 feet high and 18 feet in circumference. It was three inches thick and hollow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capital that was on it was 7½ feet high with a filigree and pomegranates around it. They were all made of bronze. The second pillar was the same. It also had pomegranates.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 96 pomegranates on the sides. The total number of pomegranates on the surrounding filigree was 100.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard took the chief priest Seraiah, the second priest Zephaniah, and the 3 doorkeepers.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the city he also took an army commander, 7 men who had access to the king whom he found in the city, the scribe who was in charge of the militia, and 60 common people whom he found in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon executed them at Riblah in the territory of Hamath. So the people of Judah were captives as they left their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the people Nebuchadnezzar took captive: In his seventh year as king, he took 3,023 Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his eighteenth year, Nebuchadnezzar took 832 people from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Nebuchadnezzar’s twenty-third year as king, Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, took away 745 Jews. In all, 4,600 people were taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month of the thirty-seventh year of the imprisonment of King Jehoiakin of Judah, King Evil Merodach of Babylon, in the first year of his reign, freed King Jehoiakin of Judah and released him from prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: He treated him well and gave him a special position higher than the other kings who were with him in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakin no longer wore prison clothes, and he ate his meals in the king’s presence as long as he lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon gave him a daily food allowance as long as he lived.
speaker: Narrator
